questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with 8-month history shortness of breath and non-productive cough. On physical examination, fine crackles are heard bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests show an FVC of 78% and FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. CT scan of the chest is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given the symptoms of shortness of breath and persistent nonproductive cough, bilateral inspiratory crackles, pulmonary function test (PFT) results, and imaging findings.

The image shows the presence of honeycombing (black arrows), traction bronchiectasis (white arrow), and a reticular pattern (black dotted arrows). The lesions are typically located along subpleural regions.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common cause of interstitial lung disease (ILD) of unknown cause. It is defined as a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown etiology, occurring in adults. It is associated with a histological or radiological pattern known as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). UIP is the typical pathological finding in patients with suspected IPF.

Patients with UIP typically present in their sixth and seventh decades of life. Men are affected more commonly than women. PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis show a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by decreased total lung capacity (TLC), forced vital capacity (FVC), residual volumes (RV), and a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio of >0.7.

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) demonstrates a characteristic pattern of peripheral (subpleural) and bibasilar reticular opacities associated with architectural distortion, including honeycomb changes and traction bronchiectasis.

Classification of ILD (based on the histopathological pattern observed on lung biopsy)

Histologic pattern Clinical syndrome
Usual interstitial pneumonia Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
Desquamative interstitial Pneumonia Desquamative interstitial pneumonia
Acute interstitial pneumonia Hamman–Rich syndrome
Bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia
Non-specific interstitial pneumonia Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
Respiratory bronchiolitis–associated lung disease Respiratory bronchiolitis– associated interstitial lung disease

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A postoperative patient comes for a follow-up visit to have his sutures removed. Which of the following blades will you use?
questions.solution:
A number-12 blade is used for suture removal.

A 12-size blade is a small, pointed, crescent-shaped blade used typically as a suture cutter. It is most sharp on the inside edge of its curve.

The number on a surgical blade communicates both its size and its shape. The different surgical blades are shown below:

Other options:

Option A: The 11-size blade has an oblique edge with a sharp-pointed tip and hence it is known as a "stab knife". 

Uses:

  • Commonly used to incise skin, subcutaneous tissue, and deep fascia to open the abscess cavity in a single stroke, during incision and drainage (I & D) of an abscess.
  • This blade can also be used for inserting drains and arteriotomy.

Option C: The 15-size blade has a narrow shaft and is often used for minor surgical procedures. 

Uses of 15-scalpel blade:

  • To make precise skin incisions in dermatosurgery
  • Minor surgical procedures
  • Select ocular procedures (15C blade)
  • Select plastic surgery procedures (15C blade)

Option D: The 10-size blade is used for skin incisions.

Note: The 22-size blade is often used for abdominal incisions. Essentially a larger version of the number 10, it has a flat, unsharpened back edge and a short, curved cutting edge. These blades are best for creating large incisions, often through thick skin. Surgical blades no. 20, 21, 22, 23, and 24 have a wide shaft and are used for larger incisions.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are contraindications for induction of labour?
  1. Intra-uterine growth restriction
  2. Placenta praevia
  3. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
  4. Placental abruption
  5. Transverse lie
questions.solution:
Among the given options, placenta praevia and transverse lie are contraindications for induction of labour.

Intra-uterine growth restriction, intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy and placental abruption are indications for induction of labour.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A leukocyte is rolling along the endothelium when it detects a site of inflammation. It traverses through the endothelial cell, exits the blood vessel and into the extracellular matrix, mediated by the PECAM-1 molecule. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
Diapedesis is the movement of leukocytes through intact endothelium of the capillaries to reach the site of injury. This process is aided by platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1).

Diapedesis occurs through the inter endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31. 

The process of acute inflammation has 3 components: An increase in blood flow due to small vessel dilation, and increased permeability of the microvasculature to aid plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation and migrate to the site of injury to exert their effects. The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

Margination and rolling: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of stasis of blood flow and start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium; Mediated by: E-Selectin, P-Selectin, Glycam-1 and CD34.
Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. Mediated by: ICAM-1, VCAM-1.
Diapedesis/Transmigration: of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium. Mediated by: PECAM-1.
Migration: towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues. Chemotactic/Inflammatory factors mediating this process: C5a, IL-8, LTB4, Kallikrein, PAF. (Options A, B and D)

Selectins, integrins, and their ligands are the most important proteins involved in adhesion and migration. Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on endothelium, and P-selectins present in platelets and on the endothelium. 

The weak rolling action slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins. Chemokines that are produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leukocytes and activate them. This in turn converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leukocytes to a high-affinity state.

This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leukocytes leads to firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.

questions.text: You are examining a  histopathological slide containing a section of hepatic tissue. You notice a dark pigmentation present in the given slide. This most likely occurs due to  ________
questions.solution:
Lipochrome or Lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen as a yellow-brown pigment in the histopathological image which can be seen in the liver and heart of aging patients. This should be distinguished from hemosiderosis, which is only seen in conditions with iron overload like hemochromatosis. 

It is also known as wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin, which is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, that accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain as a function of age. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes.
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions.
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes.
  • Prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia.

 Other options:

Option A - Anthracosis: Accumulations of carbon/coal dust pigment is seen as black accumulations in the tissues of the lungs and can lead to fibrosis and emphysema.

Option C - Alkaptonuria: In this disease, black pigment is deposited in the skin, connective tissue, and cartilage. This pigmentation is known as ochronosis.

Option D - Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived, golden-yellow to brown, granular, or crystalline pigment. It is one of the major storage forms of iron and can be seen in iron-overload states like hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man undergoes a lymph node biopsy for persistent, generalized lymphadenopathy and the biopsy is shown below. What translocation is likely associated with his condition?
questions.solution:
The histopath image shows a “starry sky” pattern - seen in Burkitt lymphoma, which exhibits a t(8;14) translocation.

Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation of the C-MYC gene on chromosome 8. This leads to increased MYC protein levels. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14).

It can occur in 3 forms that have distinct clinical characteristics:

African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands.
Sporadic (non-endemic) is often seen as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum.
Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukemia is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology shows tumor cells with round or oval nuclei, coarse chromatin, small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm, and a high mitotic index. The phagocytes have abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic “starry sky” pattern. Bone marrow aspiration shows tumor cells with royal blue cytoplasm containing clear cytoplasmic vacuoles. (Image 1)

The tumor cells express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, a phenotype consistent with a germinal center B-cell origin.

Option B: Mantle cell lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm in which tumour cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells surrounding the germinal centre. Translocation (11;14) causes overexpression of cyclin D1 proto-oncogene (Image 2)

Option C: MALToma is a lymphoma arising from mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. It is actually extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of gut mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue. It is usually primary GI lymphoma (4% of gastric lymphoma); of non-Hodgkin’s B cell type. The most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in MALT lymphomas is t(11;18). MALT lymphomas associated with t(11;18) have a good prognosis. 

Option D: Follicular lymphoma arises from germinal centre B cells and is associated with (14;18) translocation. bcl-2 is the inhibitor of apoptosis and causes the promotion of the follicular lymphoma cell. (Image 3)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about DOTS is incorrect?

choices.text: It was started as a component of RNTCP
Patients are issued medicines for a period of 1 month in the continuation phase
Patient swallows the drug in front of the health worker in the intensive phase
Patient returns an empty multi-blister pack when he comes to collect medicines

questions.solution:
As per DOTS guidelines, patients are issued medicines for a period of 1 week in the continuation phase.

DOTS stands for Directly Observed Treatment Short-course. It was added to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme as part of the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) as a cost-effective and systematic measure to advance the TB control measures in the country. The following are the major staps taken as part of DOTS to ensure patient compliance to drug regimens:

  • During the intensive phase, the patient swallows the drug in the presence of a health worker.
  • During the continuation phase, the patient is issued drugs for 1 week in a multi-blister pack.
  • The patient swallows the first dose of the continuation phase in the presence of a health worker.
  • The patient must return an empty multi-blister pack at the end of 1 week when collecting medicines for the following week.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

questions.text: A 1-day-old newborn presents with red, watery eyes after having received povidone-iodine eye drops shortly after birth. The eyelids are mildly swollen with minimal clear discharge and hyperemic conjunctiva. Which of the following is the likely outcome if left untreated?
questions.solution:
This newborn baby presenting with conjunctival hyperemia, swollen eyelids and clear discharge following prophylactic povidone-iodine eye drops is likely suffering from chemical ophthalmia neonatorum which is a self limited condition.

Ophthalmia neonatarum also called neonatal conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva occurring in an infant <30 days after birth. It should be ruled out in any infant having discharge or watering within the first week of birth. 

Chemical conjunctivitis is a toxic response to topical chemicals. It is a self limiting condition, and does not require any treatment. Recent studies suggest use of topical tetracycline and erythromycin ointment in prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum, given the higher risk of chemical conjunctivitis with povidone-iodine.

Causes of ophthalmia neonatorum include:

  1. Chlamydia: neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present the most common cause in developed countries.
  2. Gonorrhoea: effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequent decline has almost eliminated it's incidence in developed countries.
  3. Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatarum
  4. Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatorum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2 virus from the mother.
  5. Chemical conjunctivitis is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics, povidone-iodine or silver nitrate at the time of birth.
Time of presentation Causative agent
Within 48 h Chemical, Gonorrhoea
48–72 h Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae
5–7 days Herpes simplex II
>1 week Chlamydia

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with blood glucose of 620 mg/dL, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He is dehydrated and has a Kussmaul breathing pattern. His ABG: pH: 7.30, pCO2: 18 mmHg, pO2: 80 mmHg, HCO3-: 10 mEq/L, Anion gap: 16 mEq/L. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

SQ - Sub Cutaneous
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 0.9% saline and IV insulin.

This patient has diabetic ketoacidosis and should be given 0.9% saline at a rate of 1-2 liters per hour and IV insulin at a rate of 0.1 units/kg/hour. IV insulin is important as it allows for rapid administration, distribution and ease in adjustment of the infusion rate based on the patient's glucose level.

IV insulin is necessary until resolution of the acidosis - after which the infusion rate can be reduced. Once the patient is able to tolerate oral intake, SQ/subcutaneous insulin can be administered - this is important for transitioning to the outpatient SQ regime and also in reducing the length of hospital stay. (Options A, B, and D)

The diagnosis of DKA is based on the triad of hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. All three biochemical criteria are required to diagnose DKA: 

Hyperglycemia (blood glucose >200 mg/dl)
Venous pH < 7.3 or serum bicarbonate <18 mmol/L
Ketonemia or ketonuria

Initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation:

Immediate measurement of blood glucose, blood or urine ketones, serum electrolytes and blood gases
GCS should be calculated.
Two peripheral intravenous (IV) lines should be inserted.
The goal of therapy is to correct dehydration, correct acidosis, reverse ketosis, and gradually blood glucose concentration to near normal. Monitor for acute complications, and identify and treat any precipitating event.

Fluid replacement should always begin before starting insulin therapy. One or more boluses of 0.9% saline at 20 mL/kg are given to restore peripheral circulation. Insulin therapy with 0.05–0.1 U/kg/hr must begin at least 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy. Insulin of 0.05 U/kg/hr can be considered if pH is > 7.15.

Potassium replacement is given only when potassium is <5.5 mmol/L. In rare cases of hypokalemia with potassium <3.0 mmol/L, defer insulin treatment.

Bicarbonate administration is not recommended except for treatment of severe acidosis (pH < 6.9) or in cases of life-threatening hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with galactorrhea and decreased libido following haloperidol initiation for treatment of schizophrenia. Serum prolactin levels are elevated. Which of the following pathways is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient's hyperprolactinemia characterized by galactorrhea, loss of libido and following haloperidol use, is due to dopaminergic antagonism in the tuberoinfundibular pathway.

Tuberoinfundibular neurons project from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary. Dopamine is delivered in this region via the hypophyseal vessels. Dopamine binds to the D2 receptors present on the lactotropes in the anterior pituitary, and tonically inhibits prolactin secretion from these cells.

The more potent a D2 blocking drug is, the more likely it is to cause hyperprolactinemia. All first-generation antipsychotic drugs cause hyperprolactinemia due to their D2 blocking properties. Among the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone, and amisulpride are associated with hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia can induce breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and infertility in women, and sexual dysfunction in men.

There are 4 dopaminergic pathways.

Pathway Anatomy Function
Tuberoinfundibular system Cell bodies in the hypothalamus tothe pituitary stalk Inhibitory control over prolactin secretion
Nigrostriatal system Cell bodies in the substantia nigra and projects to the basal ganglia Regulating involuntary motor activity
Mesolimbic pathway Ventral tegmentum -  project diffusely to the nucleus accumbens, amygdala, hippocampus,medial dorsal nucleus of the thalamus, and cingulate gyrus Modulates emotional expression, learning and reinforcement, and hedonic capacity
Mesocortical pathway Ventral tegmentum to orbitofrontal and the prefrontal cortical regions Regulate motivation, concentration, and initiation of goal-directed and complex executive cognitive tasks

questions.text: During a rural outreach program, you interact with a 28-year-old female and her 2-year-old son. You notice that the mother appears lean and on examination find that she has pallor. Her son’s current weight for age is below the 50th percentile. Which national program would you educate these patients about?
questions.solution:
As the key issues identified in the mother and her son are anemia and malnutrition, they are part of the target population of the POSHAN Abhiyaan program.

The goals of the POSHAN Abhiyaan programme are:

  • Prevent and reduce undernutrition and stunting in children aged 0-6 years.
  • Reduce the prevalence of anemia among children aged 6 months - 6 years.
  • Reduce the prevalence of anemia among women and adolescent girls aged 15-49 years.
  • Reduce low birth weight.

Other Options:

Option A: The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free transport of pregnant women and sick infants from:

  • home to the health facilities
  • between facilities in case of a referral
  • back home from the health facilities

Option B: Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) seeks to empower adolescent girls, so as to enable them to take charge of their lives. The objectives are to:

  • improve the nutritional, health and development status of adolescent girls
  • promote awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition and family care
  • opportunities for learning life skills
  • going back to school
  • help them gain a better understanding of their social environment
  • take initiatives to become productive members of society.

Option D: Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government scheme in India to provide Rs.500 per month for TB patients to buy food.

questions.text: What is the dose and route of the birth dose of BCG vaccine?
questions.solution:
The dose of BCG vaccine for newborns (< 4 weeks ) is 0.05 ml, injected intradermally just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine such as the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation than a liquid vaccine with a longer shelf life. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination with BCG is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose for newborns (< 4 weeks ) is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe. The dose for newborns is lower as the skin in newborns is thin and a full dose might lead to abscess formation and enlarged regional lymph nodes.

 After 2-3 weeks of vaccination, a papule develops at the site of vaccination. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Normally, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include ulceration at the site of vaccination, suppurative lymphadenitis, abscess formation, osteomyelitis, disseminated BCG infection, and death.

It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text: Restriction endonuclease will act on which of the following:
questions.solution:
Restriction endonucleases can act on AAGCTT. 

Restriction endonucleases act and cleave at the site of a palindromic sequence. A palindromic sequence is a sequence that reads the same backward and forward. An example is listed below.

5' --AAGCTT-- 3'
3' --TTCGAA-- 5'

Restriction endonucleases enzymes are routinely used for DNA modification in laboratories, and they are a vital tool in molecular cloning.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient has been given an intradermal injection of 0.1ml PPD (5 tuberculin units) over the forearm.   After 72 hrs, the site is examined as shown in the image below. What is the interpretation of the result obtained?

choices.text: Tuberculin test negative, suggesting immunity from TB
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting an active infection
Tuberculin test negative, suggesting a recent or past infection
Tuberculin test positive, suggesting a recent or past infection

questions.solution:
The above image shows an induration of >10 mm after 72 hrs of intradermal PPD injection suggesting a positive tuberculin test(TST), indicating recent or past infection. 

In TST, 0.1 ml of PPD (purified protein derivative) containing 5 TU (tuberculosis unit) is injected intradermally and induration is read after 48-72 hours. An induration of 10 mm or more is considered positive in patients from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Surrounding erythema is not considered. 

A positive tuberculin test indicates hypersensitivity to tuberculoprotein, denoting either latent infection with tubercle bacilli, or BCG immunization, or recent or past infection with or without clinical disease. 

False positives may be seen in infections with related mycobacteria and false negatives in miliary tuberculosis, severely immunosuppressed states, etc.

questions.text: An obese patient was prescribed a drug for weight loss that acts by inhibiting gastrointestinal lipase. Which among the following is the prescribed drug?
questions.solution:
Orlistat is a drug indicated for weight loss and acts by inhibiting gastrointestinal lipase resulting in reduced lipid absorption.

Orlistat is a reversible gastrointestinal lipase inhibitor required for the hydrolysis of dietary fat into fatty acids and monoacylglycerols. Orlistat acts in the lumen of stomach and small intestine by forming covalent bonds with the active site of lipases. This leads to reduced digestion and absorption of dietary fat. Adverse effects include flatus with discharge, fecal urgency, fatty/oily stool, and increased defecation. These side effects are experienced early and diminish as patients control their dietary fat intake. Vitamin supplements are indicated to prevent fat soluble vitamin deficiency.

Adjuvant pharmacologic treatments for obesity should be considered for patients with a BMI ≥30 kg/m2, or for patients with a BMI ≥27 kg/m2 who have concomitant obesity-related diseases and for whom dietary and physical activity therapy has not been successful. Medications for obesity include those that affect appetite (liraglutide, phentermine)  and those that inhibit gastrointestinal fat absorption (orlistat).

Other options:

Option A: Liraglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) analogue which is approved for the treatment of type 2 diabetes, and is used as an off label indication for weight loss. It acts as an incretin hormone (glucose-induced insulin secretion), inhibits both gastric emptying and glucagon secretion and stimulates GLP-1 receptors in the arcuate nucleus of hypothalamus to reduce feeding.

Option C: Phentermine is a sympathomimetic central appetite suppressant medication that acts by increasing central norepinephrine release.

Option D: Ezetimibe selectively inhibits intestinal absorption of cholesterol and phytosterols, and is used in the management of hypercholesterolemia. It is not indicated in the treatment of obesity.

questions.text: A man presents with 10 days of fever, abdominal pain, chills, diarrhea and a generalized rash. He has a fever of 103, relative bradycardia and hepatosplenomegaly. On microbiology, an oxidase-negative, motile, gram-negative bacillus is isolated and cultured on selenite F broth. What is the most likely diagnosis and management?

choices.text: Typhoid fever; Ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID for 7 days
Shigellosis; Ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BID for 5 days
Leptospirosis; Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 7 days
Brucellosis; Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
This patient likely has Typhoid/enteric fever and the most appropriate treatment is Ciprofloxacin 500 mg PO BD for 7 days.

Clinical features include fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Some people might develop a rash - "Rose spots" on the body. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. 

Complications of enteric fever include gastrointestinal bleeding and intestinal perforation. Neurological manifestations may include meningitis, neuritis, and Guillan Barre syndrome. Other rare complications include pericarditis, myocarditis, endocarditis, pyelonephritis, glomerulonephritis, and orchitis.

Diagnosis of enteric fever includes serological testing such as the Widal test. Definitive diagnosis can be made by isolating S.Typhi or S.paratyphi from blood, bone marrow, and other sterile sites. 

The treatment of enteric fever is outlined below: 

Empirical Treatment: Ceftriaxone, 2 g/d (IV) 10-14 days or Azithromycin 1 g/d (PO) 5 days. 

Fully Susceptible = Optimal treatment: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg bid (PO) or 400 mg q12 h (IV) 7 days or Azithromycin 1 g/d (PO) 5 days.

Other options:

Option B: Shigella are gram negative, non-motile, oxidase-negative and cultured on MacConkey agar or XLD agar. Shigellosis is a spectrum of symptoms caused by shigella consisting of 4 phases: Watery diarrhea - Fever, watery diarrhea, anorexia; Dysentry: Bloody mucopurulent stools; Post-infectious complication: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome, reactive arthritis and toxic megacolon.

Option C: Leptospirosis is a spiral, motile, gram negative and oxidase positive organism. Culture - With semisynthetic media like Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media. Clinical features of mild leptospirosis include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache,  and intense conjunctival injection. The classic presentation of severe leptospirosis is referred to as Weil's disease - a triad of haemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.  Some may present as aseptic meningitis, or pulmonary leptospirosis with scattered alveolar hemorrhage. The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Option D: Brucella is a gram negative, non-motile, oxidase-positive and is cultured on blood agar. Patients with acute infection may present with undulant fever, arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with IM streptomycin and oral doxycycline. Prevention of brucellosis can be achieved by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman complains of fatigue, dry skin and cold intolerance since 2 weeks. She was started on amiodarone 1 month ago for persistent atrial fibrillation. Tests show high TSH (15 mU/l) and low free T4 levels. How would you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Thyroxine supplementation is indicated for amiodarone induced hypothyroidism which is characterized by symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, dry skin, cold intolerance) and lab findings (elevated TSH, reduced free T4) following amiodarone use.

Amiodarone induced hypothyroidism (AIH) can occur shortly after (as early as 2 weeks) amiodarone use due to iodine induced thyroid suppression (Wolff Chaikoff effect). It is characterized by clinical features of hypothyroidism and lab findings of elevated TSH and reduced free T4. It occurs more frequently in women and those with positive thyroid peroxidase antibodies. It is managed by thyroxine supplementation, without the need to discontinue amiodarone (Option A).

Amiodarone is an iodine-containing compound that is structurally related to thyroid hormone. It is a class III antiarrhythmic drug, which increases the duration of an action potential by blocking potassium channels, thereby increasing the time taken for repolarization. It is used to maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation.

Amiodarone can cause hypothyroidism due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, where excessive iodine leads to transient inhibition of organification and synthesis of thyroid hormones. Patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid disease are at increased risk of amiodarone induced hypothyroidism.

Other adverse effects of amiodarone include hypotension, bradycardia, myocardial depression, photosensitization, corneal microdeposits (corneal verticillata), pulmonary fibrosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

Other options: 

Option C: Corticosteroids would be indicated in amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis and not amiodarone induced hypothyroidism.

Option D: Patients who are asymptomatic, with subclinical hypothyroidism following amiodarone use can be managed by observation and regular monitoring with thyroid function tests. Subclinical hypothyroidism is characterized by TSH level > 4.5 and ≤ 10 mU/l, normal FT4 and absence of clinical features of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: During casualty rotations, you see a  patient who suddenly went into apnea, being ventilated with the following apparatus. What does the part marked as A represent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a self-inflating bag and mask and the part marked as A represents the oxygen inlet.

Bag and mask ventilation is used as the first step in airway management to provide positive pressure ventilation. It serves as a rescue technique to provide oxygenation and ventilation in patients with difficult airways until tracheal intubation is achieved. 

The bag in this apparatus is a self-inflating bag. This allows for it to be used without a pressurized gas supply and is delivered to the patient when the bag is squeezed (compressed). A patent airway and a good seal are essential to facilitate bag and mask ventilation.

The face mask can be used by two techniques:

  • One-handed technique: Most commonly used technique. This is achieved by ensuring a tight seal with the left-hand thumb and index finger forming a 'C' around the collar of the mask. The third and fourth digits are placed on the ramus of the mandible, and the fifth digit placed below the angle of the mandible helps in jaw thrust.
  • Two-handed technique: This is used in cases of difficult airways and it requires assistance.

Signs of effective ventilation:

  • Chest rise on squeezing the bag
  • Condensation in the clear mask
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Capnography

Mask ventilation is usually contraindicated in patients with an increased risk of regurgitation. It should be used with caution in patients with severe facial trauma.

The following image shows the parts of a self-inflating bag and mask apparatus with a reservoir bag.

questions.text: A young athlete presents with posterior shoulder pain following a blunt trauma. Which of the following tests will be performed to detect posterior shoulder instability?
questions.solution:
Posterior glenohumeral instability of the shoulder is detected by the Jerk test.

A patient may exhibit posterior instability following a traumatic shoulder dislocation or posterior shoulder pain as a result of blunt shoulder trauma. Although posterior instability is less common than anterior instability, it is becoming more prevalent in the athletic population.

The jerk test, Kim test, posterior drawer, and load-and-shift test are examination manoeuvres specifically designed to identify posterior shoulder instability.

The jerk test is highly sensitive and specific for a posterior labral tear.

  • It is performed with the patient sitting. 
  • The examiner stands close to the injured shoulder, one hand on the flexed elbow and the other on the scapular spine and distal clavicle.
  • The patient’s arm is brought into flexion and internal rotation.
  • One hand applies an anterior force through the shoulder girdle and the other applies a posterior force through the elbow to the shoulder joint.
  • A positive test result is indicated by a sharp jerk and pain as the subluxated humeral head moves into the glenoid.

Other options:

Option A: The sulcus test is used to detect inferior glenohumeral instability. This test is done with the arm in 0° and 45° of abduction where the examiner grasps the patient's arm and pulls inferiorly. If a dimple or sulcus appears beneath the acromion as the humeral head is translated inferiorly, the test is considered positive.

Option B: Jobe's test is an impingement test. The patient's arm is elevated in the scapular plane, and the elbow is extended with the thumb pointing to the floor. The patient is then asked to hold this position, while the examiner applies downward pressure. Pain indicates irritation of the supraspinatus tendon.

Option C: Hawkin-Kennedy's test is an impingement test. The patient's arm is elevated to 90° in the scapular plane with the elbow flexed to 90°. The examiner internally rotates the arm to the full extent after stabilizing the upper arm with the other hand. The test is said to be positive when there is pain in the anterolateral aspect of the shoulder.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. This means they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine examination.  On examination, a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. Lungs are clear and the abdomen is soft and non-tender.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

Atrial septal defects are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. 

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

ASDs are classified according to location of the defect listed as follows:

  • Patent foramen ovale
  • Ostium secundum
  • Ostium primum
  • Sinus venosus
  • Coronary sinus

Murmurs are described based on intensity, frequency or pitch, quality, duration, configuration, primary location, and site of radiation. The intensity of a murmur is graded from 1-6 as follows: 

  • Grade 1 - Faint, can only be heard with special effort
  • Grade 2 - Faint but immediately audible
  • Grade 3 - Moderately loud
  • Grade 4 - Very loud
  • Grade 5 - Extremely loud and is audible with one edge of the stethoscope touching the chest wall
  • Grade 6 - Loud, audible with stethoscope removed from contact with the chest wall

Murmurs of intensity grade 4 and higher are generally accompanied by a thrill. 

Other options:

Option A: Eisenmeger syndrome occurs when an existing left to right shunt results in severe pulmonary hypertension and increased vascular resistance which reverses the shunt to form a right to left shunt. Patients with known congenital heart disease would present with worsening exertional dyspnea, swelling, volume retention, syncope, cyanosis, palpitations, or hemoptysis. 

Option B: In Ventricular septal defect are generally asymptomatic and have a loud, harsh, or blowing holosystolic murmur heard over the lower left sternal border. 

Option D: Pulmonary stenosis – It has a systolic ejection murmur best heard along the left upper sternal border minimally radiating to the lung fields. Other features seen in this condition include a sharp pulmonic ejection click after S1, heard during expiration, a split S2, elevated venous pressure, prominent a wave in jugulovenous pulse, right ventricular lift, and mild to moderate cyanosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man sustained a sudden head injury as a result of which the bridging dural veins were injured. Which of the following appearance is likely to be seen in the CT Brain of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma, and the classical appearance likely to be seen in this patient is a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion.

Subdural hematoma (SDH) refers to the hemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater, and most commonly, it results from injury to the bridging dural veins. The causes of SDH include trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, and battered baby syndrome.

Acute subdural hematomas are crescent-shaped. They can cross suture lines, but they do not cross the tentorium or falx. In a non-contrast CT Brain, the acute lesions are hyperdense; subacute lesions are isodense; and chronic lesions are hypodense.

During the subacute phase with isodense lesions, the findings that are suggestive of subdural hematoma are gyral effacement and ventricular compression on the affected side and midline shift away from the affected side.

The below image shows acute subdural hematoma with a hyperdense crescentic lesion in the right posterior parietal region between the brain and the skull and a midline shift to left.

Other options:

Lentiform-shaped hyperdense lesion is seen in acute extradural hematoma. Lentiform-shaped hypodense lesion is seen in a chronic extradural hematoma. The crescent-shaped hypodense lesion is seen in chronic subdural hematoma.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A brain autopsy findings of an HIV-positive woman with dementia is given below. Her medical records show that she had progressive weakness on the right side of the body. Which of the following is the most likely opportunistic co-infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with brain autopsy findings showing ballooned oligodendrocytes with nuclear inclusion bodies suggests progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). It is caused by the JC virus.

PML is a fatal subacute progressive demyelinating disease. It is caused by the neurotrophic JC virus which belongs to the family polyomavirus. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelination throughout the brain is its principal pathologic effect, but spares the spinal cord and optic nerves.

It is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals and patients receiving monoclonal antibodies (for multiple sclerosis) and biological agents.

Patients present with insidious onset and steady progression of focal symptoms that include visual deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia), mental impairment (dementia, confusion, personality change), hemiparesis, and ataxia.

Diagnosis is with the help of an MRI brain which shows single or multiple confluent demyelinating lesions in the periventricular white matter. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the CSF is highly specific for the detection of JC virus in patients with PML.

No effective therapy is available for PML, but a 5-HT2a receptor antagonist mirtazapine is found to have beneficial effects.

The image given below shows a brain biopsy of a PML patient showing ballooned oligodendrocytes (blue arrow) with SV40 positive nuclear inclusion bodies (red arrow) and, enlarged astrocytes (yellow arrow) indicative of JC virus infection.

Other options:

Option A: Coxsackievirus B2 causes aseptic meningitis. Patients present with fever, malaise, headache, nausea, and abdominal pain. It may progress to mild muscle weakness.

Option B: Toxoplasma gondii causes toxoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It is usually associated with a history of consumption of undercooked meat. Patients present with fever, headache, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI shows ring-enhancing lesions in the brain.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV 2) can cause neurological disease (meningitis or encephalitis) presenting with fever, focal neurological deficit, and seizures. It shows focal lesions (in the temporal region) on MRI. It is diagnosed by PCR testing of HSV DNA in the CSF sample.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: The following image represents the number of cases of iron-deficiency anaemia detected in an old-age home between January 1 to December 31. How many cases would you include to calculate the period prevalence of iron deficiency in the year?
questions.solution:
7 cases will be included to calculate the period prevalence of iron deficiency in the year.

The period prevalence in this scenario includes all the cases i.e., new, old and current, that existed at any time between January 1 to December 31, represented by all the straight lines present in the given date range which are A, B, C, D, E, G, and H,  a total of 7 cases.

Other options:

Option A: 3 could be the incidence in the previous year, i.e., the number of new cases before January 1.

Option B: 4 could be the incidence in the current year, i.e., the number of new cases after January 1 and before December 31.

Option D: 8 is the total number of cases, which could be the period prevalence if the time range includes the previous, current, and following years.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Capsular polysaccharide constitutes an important virulence factor responsible for protective antibody response. In which among the following bacteria is the protective response not due to capsular polysaccharide?
questions.solution:
Among the given bacteria, the protective response in Bordetella pertussis is not due to capsular polysaccharides.

Bordetella pertussis is a gram-negative coccobacillus. It produces various virulence factors and toxins that are responsible for the clinical disease.

  • Pertussis toxin causes lymphocytosis, sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion. It can be toxoided and the toxoid form is a major component of acellular pertusis vaccines. 
  • Filamentous hemagglutinin(FHA) promotes adherence of the B.pertussis to the cilia of respiratory tract and erythrocytes. It also has a hemagglutinin activity. 
  • Pertactin is an outer membrane protein (OMP) antigen present in all virulent strains. It is part of acellular pertusis vaccines and antibody to pertactin is seen in blood after immunization or infection in children
  • Tracheal cytotoxin causes destruction of the ciliated cells in the trachea. 
  • Other virulence factors- Includes Adenylate cyclase, heat-labile toxin, lipopolysaccharide.

  • Several groups of streptococci

  • Klebsiella
  • Haemophilus influenza
  • Yersinia

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts the Ritgen’s maneuver.

Ritgen’s maneuver:

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exerts upward pressure to the chin and extends the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counter pressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The ritgen’s maneuver thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus.

Other options:

Option b: Pinard’s maneuver is used to facilitate the delivery of legs in case of frank breech presentation.

Option c: Lovset’s maneuver is used to facilitate the delivery of arms in breech presentation.

Option d: In zavanelli maneuver the fetal head is rotated to the pre restitution position and pushed back into the pelvis. The fetus is then delivered by caesarean section.

questions.text: The optical coherence tomography image in a patient with an acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia is given below. What will be the finding on fundus fluorescein angiography?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and OCT image showing fluid in the subretinal space and is suggestive of central serous retinopathy (CSR). FFA finding in CSR includes smokestack appearance and inkblot/enlarging dot appearance.

CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. It occurs due to an abnormal choroidal circulation leading to an increase in fluid in the subretinal space.

Two patterns of FFA are seen in CSR. They are:

  • Inkblot pattern or enlarging dot appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size.
  • Smokestack appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot which ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom.

Other options:

  • Stars in sky appearance - Seen in drusens
  • Petaloid appearance - Seen in cystoid macular edema
  • Dual circulation - Seen in choroidal melanoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old otherwise healthy male presents with paroxysmal episodes of palpitations, shortness of breath, and lightheadedness. The episodes typically last for a few minutes and resolve spontaneously. An EKG is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely origin of this EKG finding?

choices.text: Foci of automaticity in the Purkinje system

questions.solution:
Narrow complex tachycardia without visible P waves and sudden onset palpitations as shown in the ECG suggests AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) which is most commonly due to an AV nodal re-entry circuit.

This is the most common type of PSVT, accounting for about 60% of all cases. It occurs when an electrical signal gets trapped in a circuit within the AV node, causing it to fire rapidly and repeatedly, causing a re-entry circuit. This results in a regular narrow QRS complex tachycardia.

The given ECG strip shows changes suggestive of AV node reentry tachycardia based on the following findings:

Narrow QRS complex tachycardia at 150 bpm, indicative of a regular atrial rate (1:1 AV response). Heart rate is calculated by dividing 300 by the number of large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves. The ECG strip shows the presence of roughly 2 large boxes between 2 consecutive R waves, thereby making the HR ~150 bpm.
No visible P waves - indicative of dual conduction pathways (slow and fast) that cause simultaneous atrial and ventricular activation.
The P wave may sometimes be seen at the end of the QRS complex as a pseudo-r' wave (V1) and pseudo-S wave. (II, III, aVF)

Other options:

Option B: Accessory pathway between atrium and ventricle: This can allow electrical signals to bypass the AV node. Wolf Parkinson White is a type of preexcitation syndrome, i.e., abnormally early ventricular excitation, which in WPW, occurs via a bypass tract (Bundle of Kent). Normally, there is a normal AV nodal delay to allow adequate ventricular filling. The bypass tract allows impulses to skip the nodal delay leading to preexcitation of the ventricles. In this syndrome, there is both preexcitation and delayed conduction leading to a shortened PR interval (< 0.12 secs) and wide QRS. There is a characteristic delta wave notch in the QRS wave.

Option C: Automaticity from multiple atrial foci: Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a type of PSVT caused by multiple atrial foci discharging independently at a rapid rate, this can occur due to lung pathology such as COPD. This results in an irregular narrow QRS complex tachycardia.

Option D: Foci of automaticity in the Purkinje system: Leads to ventricular arrhythmias, which would be charcterized by a wide QRS.

questions.text: A female patient is being evaluated for breast carcinoma. Which of the following subtypes of breast cancer has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast has the worst prognosis.

Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

The diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer are:

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema and/or peau d’orange, and/or warm breast (with or without an underlying palpable mass)
  • Duration of history no more than six months
  • Erythema occupying at least one-third of the breast
  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma

Cut-off of 6 months for the duration of history differentiates between inflammatory breast carcinoma (≤6 months) and locally advanced breast cancer with secondary erythema (>6 months).

The pathologic hallmark is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis.

Mammography may be normal or show skin thickening. A PET-CT scan should be considered at the time of diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Combined-modality treatment is used, which includes:

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Modified radical mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)
  • Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors)

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with painless progressive swelling over the past 2 years as shown below. He is a chronic smoker. On examination, the mass is 5-cm firm, movable, there is the displacement of tonsillar pillars and the swelling is variable in consistency. Post-surgery biopsy revealed the epithelial elements to be resembling ductal cells and myoepithelial cells arranged as ducts, acini and sheets of cells. Which of the following statements regarding this tumor is true?

choices.text: Most commonly affects male gender and smokers
Most common salivary gland tumor in adults.
Open biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice
Facial nerve is commonly involved in this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image depicts a case of pleomorphic adenoma. The only true statement regarding pleomorphic adenoma is that it is the most common salivary gland tumor in adults.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • The most commonly affected gland is the parotid gland. 
  • The superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called the mixed tumor, since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females (Option -A) around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • The involvement of the deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumour – swelling in both the neck and oral cavity.

Specific features:

  • Slowly growing benign tumour
  • Unicentric in origin
  • Potentially malignant
  • Possibility of protrusion of fringes of the tumour mass through the capsule
  • Radioresistant
  • Usually affects adults, females > males
  • Painless swelling
  • Well-defined margins
  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard consistency
  • Free from deeper structures
  • No facial nerve involvement (Option-D)
  • The deep lobe pushes tonsils and faucial pillars

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to the facial nerve and seedling of the tumour (Option-C)

Treatment: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation). Radiotherapy is considered in high-grade malignancies demonstrating extra-glandular disease, perineural invasion , direct invasion of surrounding tissue, or regional metastases.

Note: Malignant change occurs in about 1.5 to 9.5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of the mastoid tip.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

 

Microscopic features:

  • The epithelial elements resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • These epithelial elements are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: In patients undergoing which of the following procedures do prophylactic antibiotics have no role in preventing surgical site infection?
questions.solution:
Thyroidectomy is an example of a clean incised wound and antibiotic prophylaxis does not change the outcome of the patient in terms of SSI (surgical site infection) 

A surgical site infection (SSI) rate is the least in clean wounds, i.e in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. 

SSI rates related to wound contamination with and without using antibiotic prophylaxis:

Type of surgery

Infection rate without antibiotic prophylaxis (%)

Infection rate with prophylaxis (%)

Clean (no viscus opened)

 1-2 1-2

Clean-contaminated(viscus opened, minimal spillage)

 6-9 3

Contaminated (open viscus with spillage or inflammatory disease)

 13-20 6

Dirty (pus or perforation, or incision through an abscess)

Other options:

Laparoscopic abdominal hysterectomy and elective appendicectomy are examples of clean-contaminated wounds and the risk of SSI after administering antibiotics are nearly halved. 

Emergency cholecystectomy is a contaminated wound where gastrointestinal inflammation is present, with no purulent discharge. Antibiotics are indicated and are to be given 30 minutes to 1 hour before surgery. Colorectal fistulectomy, most commonly from malignant lesions is a dirty wound (IV) where the field is contaminated with fecal matter. Antibiotics nearly reduce the risk of SSI by 5 times.

Surgical wounds Classification:

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks unsterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text:
A 36-year-old primigravida comes to the clinic at 31-weeks gestation with complaints of intolerable pruritus at night, particularly in her palms and soles. She also has right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and poor appetite. Her laboratory investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the appropriate management for her condition?
Liver Function Tests Values
Bilirubin (mg/dL) 4
Aspartate aminotransferase (U/L) 180
Alanine aminotransferase (U/L) 200
Alkaline phosphatase (U/L) 250
Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (U/L) 60
Albumin (g/dL) 3
Prothrombin time (s) 11

An infectious disease panel is negative.
questions.solution:
This patient at 31 weeks gestation with intolerable pruritus over her palms and soles at night, right upper quadrant pain, nausea, poor appetite, and abnormal liver function tests is likely to have intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. 

Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy is also known as recurrent jaundice of pregnancy, icterus gravidarum, or cholestatic hepatosis. It occurs during the late 2nd and early 3rd trimesters. The etiology is not well understood but is thought to be due to a relation between the cholestatic properties of reproductive hormones in genetically susceptible women. 

It usually presents with intense pruritus after 30 weeks of gestation over the palms and soles and is worse at night. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, dark urine, and pale stool. 

Hyperbilirubinemia results from retention of conjugated pigment, but total plasma concentrations rarely exceed 4 to 5 mg/dL. Serum transaminase levels are normal to moderately elevated and may occasionally reach levels up to 1000 mg/dL. Alkaline phosphatase levels are usually elevated. Liver biopsy shows mild cholestasis with bile plugs in the hepatocytes and canaliculi of the centrilobular region.

Management:

  • Antihistamines and topical emollients 
  • Cholestyramine
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis. Which of the following dietary modifications would you recommend to reduce the risk of future stone formation?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate advice is for the patient to lower protein intake in their diet.

High protein intake, particularly from animal sources, can increase urinary sulfate levels, contributing to acidic urine and potentially increasing calcium, oxalate, and uric acid excretion. High protein intake also leads to decreased urinary citrate excretion, which further promotes stone formation. Limiting protein intake helps maintain a neutral urinary pH and reduces the excretion of calcium, oxalate, and uric acid while preserving urinary citrate levels, thereby reducing the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation. 

Other options:

Option A: Excessive dietary sodium intake can increase renal sodium and calcium excretion, leading to hypercalciuria, a contributing factor to calcium oxalate stone formation. Therefore, increasing dietary sodium intake is not recommended for patients with recurrent calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis.

Option C: While it may seem counterintuitive, *restricting dietary calcium intake can actually increase the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation. This is because the body compensates for the reduced calcium intake by increasing intestinal absorption of oxalate, leading to hyperoxaluria. Hyperoxaluria, in turn, increases the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation. Therefore, lowering calcium intake is not recommended for patients with recurrent calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis.

Option D: Urinary citrate plays a crucial role in preventing calcium oxalate stone formation by inhibiting crystal formation and promoting stone dissolution. Therefore, lowering citrate intake can increase the risk of calcium oxalate stone formation. Hence, maintaining adequate citrate levels through dietary choices is essential for preventing recurrent calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis.
