questions.text: A 7 year old child presents to the clinic with the following skin lesion. Which of the following is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
This "classic" bull's-eye rash is also called erythema migrans. This lesion is usually seen in individuals with Lyme’s disease.
In children with Lyme disease amoxicillin is the drug of choice.

Doxycycline is generally the drug of choice in Lyme’s disease except in pregnant, lactating women and children under 8 where amoxicillin is used.
Doxycycline is preferred because it has excellent CNS penetration and it can be used to treat anaplasmosis which can coexist with the Lyme’s disease.

Ceftriaxone is reserved for patients with late neurological findings.
Although Azithromycin can be used for treatment treating with amoxicillin gave superior results and shorter treatment time.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a history of progressive dysphagia, heartburn, and a sensation of food getting stuck in his chest, despite PPI therapy. An endoscopy is done and is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is topical steroids.

The endoscopy image shows presence of linear furrows and multiple corrugated rings throughout a narrowed esophagus called feline esophagus or trachealization of the esophagus, suggestive of EoE. The diagnosis requires biopsy with histologic finding of > 15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. The main symptoms of EoE are difficulty swallowing (dysphagia), vomiting, and food impactions.

Symptoms include food impaction, dysphagia, vomiting, and GERD-like symptoms. Children present with feeding intolerance and GERD-like symptoms. Patients are usually atopic and may also have atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or modest peripheral eosinophilia.

Treatment: Patients typically undergo a trial of PPI therapy to exclude GERD. 30–50% of cases respond to PPI therapy, and this patient seems to have not responded to PPIs.

Children have been effectively treated with allergy testing combining skin prick and atopy patch testing. Both adults and children responded to empiric elimination of common food allergies (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, and seafood) followed by systematic reintroduction.

Swallowed, topical glucocorticoids like fluticasone propionate or budesonide are highly effective as long as they are taken. Systemic glucocorticoids are reserved for severely afflicted patients refractory to less morbid treatments.

Esophageal dilation is very effective at relieving dysphagia in patients with fibro stenosis/strictures but is approached conservatively because of the risk of deep, esophageal mural laceration or perforation in the stiff-walled esophagus. (Option A)

Oral diphenhydramine (Option C) is an antihistamine. However, it is not an effective treatment for EoE.

Montelukast (Option D) is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that is used to treat asthma and allergic rhinitis. It has not been shown to be effective in the treatment of EoE.

questions.text: A 13-year old boy with 70 kg weight and hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. Which of the following signs will be positive?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in the above case is slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE). Trethowan's sign is seen in SCFE.

Points in favor of SCFE:

  • 13-year old child: As SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, commonly during 11-20 years, due to the weakening of upper femoral physis. Most common age of presentation of Perthe's disease is 4-8 years.
  • Obesity and hypothyroidism: Obesity, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, hyperparathyroidism, growth hormone excess, Turner's syndrome, Klinefelter's syndrome, and chronic renal failure are all important associations of SCFE.
  • Limitation of abduction and internal rotation
  • Tenderness in scarpa's triangle

Trethowan's sign is seen in SCFE. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign.

Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.

 

Other options:

Siffert Katz sign: In Blount's disease, the knee is stable in full extension, but the medial femoral condyle may sublux posteromedially (into the depressed medial tibial plateau) at 10-20 degrees of flexion. This is called Siffert-katz sign.

The increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate has been named the Terry Thomas sign after the gap-toothed smile. A scapholunate gap of >3 mm is suggestive of instability, with a gap >5 mm diagnostic of SLD if there is a positive cortical ring sign.

Spur sign: Seen in transverse fracture of acetabulum.

questions.text: You are assessing a patient with Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus. What type of gait would you expect to see?

choices.text: Excessive hip flexion and slapping of one foot

questions.solution:
Broad-based and shuffling is the most likely gait you would expect to see in a patient with Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH). 

This gait is characterized by a wide/broad-base, shuffling, short strides, and hesitation with starting and turning.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with a characteristic clinical triad of ataxia in the form of broad/wide-based gait (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, and dementia. Since intracranial pressure is normal, there will be no papilledema in patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus (non-obstructive hydrocephalus) caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

On imaging, dilated lateral ventricles are seen. Lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the normal to high range.

Treatment includes ventricular shunting. Gait improves more than cognition.

Option A. Unsteady, falling towards one side is suggestive of a vestibular condition such as Meniere's disease, vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis.

Option B. Short steps, shuffling and festinant is a description of festinating gait, which is seen in Parkinson's disease.

Option C. Excessive hip flexion and slapping of one foot is a description of slapping gait, which is seen in motor neuropathy - eg common peroneal neuropathy.

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for hearing loss. Rinne’s test shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralizes to the left ear. What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the inference of the tuning fork tests is Weber's test lateralized to the left ear and Rinne's test normal. So the diagnosis is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

Tuning fork tests are performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, 1024, etc. The tuning fork of 512 Hz is considered ideal as forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time. Some examples of commonly done tuning fork tests are as follows:

Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC). The inferences are as follows:

  • Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in normal people and people with sensorineural deafness.
  • It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. It suggests a minimum hearing loss of 15-20 dB.

 Weber test is done by placing a vibrating tuning in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. The inferences are as follows:

  • Normal result is achieved when the sound heard equally in both ears
  • In conductive deafness, it is lateralized to the worse ear
  • In sensorineural deafness, it is lateralized to the better ear

Other options: 

Option A: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC) and Weber's test lateralized to the right ear. 

Option B: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear presents with a negative Rinne's test (BC>AC)and Weber's test is lateralized towards the left ear.

Option D: Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear presents with a positive Rinne's test (AC>BC) and Weber's test is lateralized towards the right ear.

questions.text: The employees of an office are informed that there would be an inspection in the afternoon as part of an evaluation of their productivity. In the afternoon, all employees achieve their daily targets before the usual time. This is an example of?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of the Hawthorne effect, which is a type of bias in which the behaviour or attitude of the participants in a study change when they are aware that they are being observed, which may not be reflective of their activity under natural circumstances.

This can be prevented by blinding or using a placebo group.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: A 70-year old diabetic female complains of frequent urination, but no pain or burning micturition. She has an urgency to pass the urine but passes urine before reaching the lavatory.  Which of the following drugs is not indicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of urge incontinence or overactive bladder and Duloxetine is not useful in this case.

Duloxetine is not useful in detrusor instability. It is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that is indicated in depression, fibromyalgia, and neuropathic pain.

Muscarinic antagonists increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder. M3 receptor selectivity is shown by solifenacin and darifenacin. Tolterodine also shows a preference for muscarinic receptors on the bladder.

The effects of muscarinic antagonists on the bladder are:

  • Lowering of intravesicular pressure
  • Increases bladder capacity
  • Lower the frequency of bladder contractions
  • Alter bladder sensation during filling

questions.text: What is the area marked as 'A' in the image below?
questions.solution:
The area marked 'A' in the image is the body/trunk of the corpus callosum which connects both the temporal lobes. 

The genu or rostrum of the corpus callosum can be visualised when you also visualise the septum pellucidum (thin wall separating the two frontal horns of the lateral ventricle) in a coronal section. The body of the corpus callosum can be visualised when you see the thalamus, caudate nucleus, pons and crus cerebri of the midbrain in a coronal section. The splenium of the corpus callosum becomes apparent in cases where the cerebellum can be visualised along with the non-visualisation of structures mentioned above.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: A 25-year-old trekker without any past medical history is trying to scale the Mount Everest. He ascends 3500 ft in 7 hours and develops severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. He continues climbing and develops altered mental status, ataxia and urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the primary treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
This patient had develoepd High-Altitude Cerebral Edema, and Dexamethasone is the primary treatment for HACE.

HACE is a on the spectrum of altitude-related neurologic conditions associated with rapid ascent. It is an encephalopathy which rapidly causes ataxia, altered consciousness, severe fatigue, incontinence, focal neurologic deficits, seizures due to diffuse cerebral involvement. These symptoms may progress to even coma and death.

This must be distinguished from AMS (Acute Mountain Sickness) that presents with headache, drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, etc. HACE includes the severe symptoms of AMS and occurs due to cerebral hypoxia and the resultant vasogenic edema. 

General management of of AMS or HACE: The most essential and definitive step is immediate descent. In cases where this isn't possible, hyperbaric chambers can be used for symptom relief. Initial treatment also includes maintaining oxygen saturaton over 90% with O2 therapy if needed.

Mild AMS: Acetazolamide is helpful for both prophylaxis and treatment of mild AMS.

Moderate-Severe AMS and HACE: Dexamethasone is the primary treatment, and must be given until 24 hours post symptom resolution. This helps reduce vasogenic edema and provides rapid relief of cerebral edema symptoms. Acetazolamide is an adjunct treatment here and is not necessarily helpful.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has complaints of painless cervical lymphadenopathy with fever, malaise, and weight loss. A lymph node was biopsied and the findings are as shown below.  All are true about the condition except

choices.text: Involves single axial group of lymph nodes

questions.solution:
The lymph node shows classical Reed-Sternberg cell seen in Hodgkin lymphoma. Mesenteric nodes are infrequently involved in Hodgkin lymphoma.

Hodgkin lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single node and spreads from the nodes to spleen, then the liver, and finally bone marrow.

The clinical importance of this predictable route of spread is highlighted by the importance of staging which determines prognosis as well the treatment of HL.

questions.text: A 20-year-old who was found missing for the past three days was later found in a swimming pool nearby. On examination, parts of the faded tattoo were found remaining on his back. Which of the following tests can best reveal the presence of a tattoo in its entirety?
questions.solution:
Infrared photography makes old tattoos readily visible. Also, due to its non-invasive nature and micron-level resolution along with the use of common equipment in forensic laboratories, has placed this technique over others in visualising faded tattoo marks.

A faded tattoo mark can be visualized by:

  • Ultraviolet light
  • Infrared photography
  • Rubbing the part and examining it with a magnifying lens
  • 3% Hydrogen peroxide

In decomposed bodies, the tattoo marks can be visualized by removing the epidermis with a moist cloth. The lymph nodes near a tattoo mark also show a deposit of the pigment.

Other options:

Option A: A magnifying lens can be used but is inferior to infrared photography.

Option C: Although optical coherence tomography can be used to visualise faded tattoos, the increased technical skill required to utilise this technique makes it not very viable.

Option D: Hydrogen peroxide can also be used to visualise faded tattoos but due to its destructive nature it has been replaced by the use of infrared photography. Also, prior knowledge of the existence of a tattoo at the location is required prior to the application of hydrogen peroxide.

questions.text: Hide-and-die syndrome is a feature of:
questions.solution:
The hide-and-die syndrome/Terminal burrowing behaviour is seen in some cases of hypothermic death.

The hypothermia victim attempts to protect himself from the cold by hiding himself in corners, cupboards or furniture. When the person is outdoors, he may burrow into snow. The behaviour is thought to result from disorientation due to hypothermia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent ear infections and a skin rash. During the workup, the finding below is seen on electron microscopy. What other marker will likely be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Birbeck granules are cytoplasmic organelles that are characteristic of Langerhans cells histioctyosis. S100 is a family of proteins that are also expressed by Langerhans cells. Therefore, a patient with Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is likely to have a positive S100 test.

Histopathologically, it is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells. The tumour cells contain abundant cytoplasm with folded or grooved nuclei. Ultrastructurally, they contain tennis-racket-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions called Birbeck granules. The tumour cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The most common gene mutated in LCH is the BRAF gene. Activation of the valine-to-glutamate substitution at residue 600 in BRAF gene is seen in LCH. Less common mutations have also been detected in TP53, RAS, and the receptor tyrosine kinase MET. 

BRAF mutations are also seen in conditions like hairy cell leukaemia, colon adenocarcinoma, melanoma, papillary thyroid carcinoma. 

LCH is a spectrum of clonal proliferations of immature dendritic cells called the Langerhans cells. It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can also infiltrate nearly every organ, like the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system. 

LCH can present as the following clinical entities: Multifocal multisystem LCH (Letterer-Siwe disease) - mostly seen in infants
Unifocal and multifocal unisystem LCH (eosinophilic granuloma)- The combination of bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is called the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad - mostly seen in older children, adults
Pulmonary LCH - mostly seen in adults

Clinical features include: Often asymptomatic. Dyspnea, cough, bone pain, abnormal growth of soft tissue over the affected bone, rash, pruritus, increased thirst, and lymphadenopathy.
Fatigue, generalized weakness, weight loss, night sweats, nausea, and fever may also occur.

Other important markers:

  • GATA3: Primary lung adenocarcinoma, small cell carcinoma, thyroid neoplasms both primary and metaplastic
  • Chromogranin: Neuroendocrine tumors (Option A)
  • CD117: GIST Tumors, Mast cell tumors, malignant melanoma, clear cell sarcoma (Option D)
  • CD1a: Histiocytosis X
  • Calretinin: Adrenal cortical neoplasm, mesothelial origin tumors, sex-chord stromal tumors (Option B)
  • Desmin: Rhabdomyosarcoma, smooth muscle tumor
  • Vimentin: Pancreatic cancer, endometrial carcinoma
  • S100: Urothelial carcinoma, Melanoma, Pancreatic ductal carcinoma, Chordoma, Histocytosis X

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida did not know that she was pregnant until she began to show. She has not had any previous antenatal visits and has never taken iron or folic acid supplements. Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the diagram below is also found in?
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the given image is the first carpometacarpal joint which is a saddle type of synovial joint and can also be found in between the femur and patella.

questions.text: Which of the following sequence related to physical changes that occurs during pubertal development in males is correct?

choices.text: Growth of testis > Pubarche > Adrenarche >Growth spurt
Growth of testis > Adrenarche > Pubarche>Growth spurt

questions.solution:
Growth of testis > pubarche > adrenarche > growth spurt (TPAG) is the correct sequence related to physical changes that occurs during pubertal development in males. 

The correct sequence of physical changes that occur during pubertal development in males is as follows:

  1. Growth of testis: The growth of the testis (> 4 mL in volume) is the first sign of puberty in males.In males at 11 to 12 years, the growth of the testis > 4 mL in volume and thinning of the scrotum occurs, which are the first signs of puberty, followed by the pigmentation of the scrotum, growth of the penis, and by pubarche.
  2. Pubarche: Appearance of pubic hair.
  3. Adrenarche
  4. Growth spurt

In females at 10 to 11 years, the breast bud (thelarche) appears, which is the first sign of puberty followed by the appearance of pubic hair (pubarche), growth spurt, and menarche. Thelarche > pubarche > growth spurt > menarche (TPGM).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of productive cough, sputum production, chest pain, and mild dyspnea. He denies fever, chills, or hemoptysis. Acute bronchitis is suspected. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Acute bronchitis is an inflammation of the large airways, most commonly caused by viruses (95% of cases) and is self-limiting. Bacterial infections are rare. In some instances, allergens, irritants, and bacteria can trigger acute bronchitis. Smoke inhalation, polluted air exposure, and dust are examples of irritants.

The symptoms of acute bronchitis include productive cough, sputum production, chest pain, and mild dyspnea. Fever, chills, and hemoptysis are less common. Sputum or occassional hemoptysis may occur due to sloughing, and do not necessarily indicate bacterial infection.

The diagnosis of acute bronchitis is usually made clinically. Chest X-rays may be used to rule out other causes of cough, such as pneumonia if bronchitis doesn't resolve.

Guidelines recommend against antibiotic use in acute bronchitis. Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment for acute bronchitis. This includes rest, fluids, and over-the-counter medications to relieve symptoms, such as cough suppressants and expectorants. (Options A, B and C)

questions.text: Which of the following anti-metabolites act as an antifungal agent?
questions.solution:
Flucytosine is an anti-metabolite that acts as an antifungal agent.

Fungal cytosine deaminase converts flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil, which is an anticancer drug. 5-fluorouracil is further converted into metabolites that inhibit thymidylate synthase, an enzyme that is necessary for DNA synthesis. Thus fungal DNA synthesis is inhibited. Mammalian cells are spared as it lacks cytosine deaminase enzyme.

Flucytosine has clinically useful activity (3C) against

  • Cryptococcus
  • Candida albicans
  • Chromoblastomycosis

The current pharmacological utility of flucytosine is in the treatment of HIV-associated cryptococcal meningitis (in combination with amphotericin B) and in chromoblastomycosis (in combination with itraconazole).

Other options:

Option A - Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits the enzymes dihydrofolate reductase and thymidylate synthase. It impairs de novo synthesis of purine nucleotides. It is used in the management of breast, head & neck, bladder cancers as well as lymphomas (primary central nervous system lymphoma, non-Hodgkin's).

Option B - Cladribine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) that inhibits the enzyme ribonucleotide reductase (impaired formation of deoxyribonucleotides) and integrates cladribine triphosphate into DNA (renders DNA non-functional). It is used to treat hairy cell leukemia, CLL, and lymphoma.

Option C - Clofarabine is an antimetabolite (purine nucleoside analog) with action similar to that of cladribine. questions.text: The cords of the brachial plexus are named due to their close relation to which part of the axillary artery?
questions.solution:
The cords of the brachial plexus are named due to their close relation to the second part of the axillary artery. 

The lateral cord which is formed by the union of the anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks lies anterior to the axillary artery. The medial cord which is formed by the union of the anterior division of the lower trunk lies medial to the axillary artery and the posterior cord which is formed by the fusion of the posterior divisions of all the trunks lies posterior to the axillary artery. 

This has been diagrammatically represented as follows:

The axillary artery represents the extension of the subclavian artery. The axillary artery spans from the outer border of the 1st rib to the inferior margin of the teres major muscle, at which point it transitions into the brachial artery. The pectoralis minor muscle traverses the artery, resulting in its division into three distinct parts.

  • 1st part - Superior Thoracic artery
  • 2nd part - Thoracoacromial artery and Lateral Thoracic artery
  • 3rd part - Subscapular, Anterior circumflex humeral and Posterior circumflex artery

Also, clinically while performing a brachial nerve plexus block it is important to locate the axillary sheath which can be localised by palpating the 3rd part of the axillary artery.

The image shows a local anaesthetic being injected into the tip of the axilla around the axillary artery. This is the method used to perform the axillary block. It reliably produces anesthesia of the entire arm distal to the elbow, and so can be used for all of the given procedures, except fixation of the shaft of the humerus. The terminal branches of the brachial plexus can be blocked via the axillary approach.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy slipped and injured his wrist while hurrying to his lecture class, after which he developed numbness over the right thumb as well as the second and third fingers. On examination, swelling was noted on the right wrist with Tinel's sign being positive. X-rays performed are as follows. Which of the following is the likely cause of this patient's present condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is indicative of carpal tunnel syndrome(CTS) caused by lunate dislocation as shown in both AP and lateral X-rays.

A fracture of the ulnar styloid is present but has no role in the development of carpal tunnel syndrome in this patient. The AP projection reveals an alteration in the typical alignment of the proximal carpal row, wherein the lunate assumes a triangular configuration and is positioned over the capitate bone.  The presence of lunate dislocation has been verified based on the findings observed in the lateral radiographic image. Lunate dislocation is commonly associated with median nerve injury. It is caused by high-energy traumatic injuries especially when the wrist is extended and ulnarly deviated. Patients present with acute wrist swelling and pain. 

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) refers to the complex of symptoms and signs brought on by compression of the median nerve as it travels through the carpal tunnel. 

Clinical features:

  • Pain, paresthesia of the first three digits, and the radial half of the fourth digit. The symptoms are worse at night relieved by shaking or wringing their hands or by placing them under warm running water. It may progress to weakness and clumsiness of the hand.
  • Durkan's test is the most specific test for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome. In Durkan's test, direct median nerve compression is done. The presence of paresthesias and pain denotes median nerve compression.
  • Phalen's test - Elicited by holding the wrist flexed fully. The appearance of sensory symptoms within 60 seconds implies a positive test. 
  • Tinel's sign - Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve.

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies are done to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Clinical grading of CTS -

  • Mild -  Numbness, tingling, or discomfort in the median nerve distribution but no sensory loss, weakness, sleep disruption, or interference with activities of daily living (ADLs)
  • Moderate - Sensory loss in the median distribution, or if nocturnal symptoms occasionally disrupt sleep. However, ADLs are normal
  • Severe - If nocturnal symptoms routinely disrupt sleep, weakness in the median distribution, or the patient is unable to carry out ADLs.

Treatment: 

In cases of mild clinical symptoms splinting or glucocorticoid injections may be first tried. Additionally in cases where it is pregnancy-induced wrist splinting may provide respite without the need for surgical interventions as the cause is transient and symptoms improve upon delivery. Surgical decompression is recommended for severe CTS or if non-surgical management fails.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a diabetic foot. The plan is to amputate the foot at the level of A-B as shown below. What is the amputation at this level called?
questions.solution:
This level of amputation is called Syme's amputation.

Amputation at the level distal tibia and fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of the ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. It is the most satisfactory functional level in the lower extremity when the outcome is good. The most common causes of an unsatisfactory Syme stump are posterior migration of the heel pad and skin slough resulting from overly vigorous trimming of “dog ears” or a compromised posterior tibial artery. The chief objection to this amputation is cosmetic.

Sarmiento modification of Syme technique is transection of the tibia and fibula approximately 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of the medial and lateral malleoli.

questions.text: A patient presents with bloody diarrhea 3 days after he ate meat at a wildlife camp. Stool cultures reveal an organism that grows well at high temperatures. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with bloody diarrhoea after eating probably undercooked meat at a wildlife camp. The organism growing at higher temperatures indicates that it is a thermophile. Out of the given options, only Campylobacter jejuni is a thermophilic organism. It needs to be incubated at 42° C in order for growth to occur.

Campylobacter is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus. Growth occurs under microaerophilic conditions. The organism also shows darting motility. Asymptomatic campylobacter infection also may trigger Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. In C. jejuni infection, bacterial lipopolysaccharide trigger an autoimmune response against axons via molecular mimicry, hence causing GBS.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a cortical screw.

Identification points for the screws are:

  • Cortical screw: Threaded whole length, smaller thread, low pitch, compression produced by over drilling proximal cortex
  • Cancellous screw: Larger thread, high pitch, compression by partial threading with a blunt tip
  • Malleolar screw: Modified cancellous screw with a sharp-pointed tip

Most orthopedic implants are made of titanium-based alloys because they are highly resistant to corrosion.

questions.text: During routine USG examination of a G2P1L1 woman, you note findings suggestive of placenta increta. What is the pathology involved in this condition?

choices.text: Villi are attached to lower uterine segment

questions.solution:
In placenta increta, the chorionic villi invade the myometrium.

Accrete syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive or adhered placenta. These occur due to:

  • Partial or total absence of the decidua basalis 
  • Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.  

The various types of morbidly adherent placenta are:

Types

Definition

Placenta accreta

(most common)  

Villi are attached to the myometrium

Placenta increta 

Villi invade the myometrium

Placenta percreta 

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa

 

Note: Villi are attached to the lower uterine segment in placenta previa.

 

Investigations that help in diagnosing these conditions:

  • USG
  • Color Doppler 
  • MRI 

 

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

 

The image below shows placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

questions.text: You are assessing a sample of water for fecal contamination which had a negative coliform count and performing the test shown below. What is the interpretation of the same?

choices.text: Contamination occured a long time ago
Sample has been cross contaminated by another sample

questions.solution:
The image shows stormy fermentation of lactose in litmus milk. This finding is caused by Clostridium perfingens type A.

The fermentation of lactose by this organism leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

Clostridium perfringens also occur regularly in feces but in much smaller numbers than E.coli. The spores are capable of surviving in water for a long time, and they usually resist chlorination. The presence of spores of Clostridium perfringens in natural water suggests that fecal contamination has occurred. But in the absence of the coliform group, it suggests that fecal contamination is a long time ago. They can also be used to assess filtration systems.

questions.text: Capnography tracings corresponding to esophageal intubation and malignant hyperthermia are:

choices.text: Graph A and Graph D  respectively
Graph C and Graph D respectively
Graph B and Graph F  respectively
Graph C and Graph B  respectively

questions.solution:
Esophageal intubation will show graph C on capnography and malignant hyperthermia will show Graph D on capnography.

Capnography is the quantitative method used to assess ventilation during the perioperative period. It provides a graphical representation of CO2 concentrations as a function of time or volume. A normal time capnograph displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases, with the expiratory phase divided into three distinct components as shown in the image below:

In oesophageal intubation, there is an initial peak of the graph showing end-tidal CO2 due to some amount of swallowed expired air present in the stomach. Subsequently, the graph approaches zero due to washing out of this swallowed air in a few breaths.

Malignant hyperthermia is characterized by hypoventilation. In this, there is a progressive rise in the end-tidal CO2 due to the increased metabolic rate. Patient develops sustained muscle contraction and hyperthermia following the administration of succinylcholine and other inhaled anesthetics like halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, etc. It is due to the mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19.

The mutated Ryr 1 leads to an increase in intracellular calcium which removes the inhibition of troponin, resulting in uncontrolled muscle contraction and an increase in adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) activity. This causes an uncontrolled hypermetabolic state with increased oxygen consumption and CO2 production. Dantrolene therapy is the treatment of choice.

Other graphs: 

A- shows clefts in the plateau phase of expiration known as curare clefts. This indicates spontaneous breathing efforts by the patient.

B-  shows elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing.

E - Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patients.

F - Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression.

G- Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuits.

questions.text: A patient complains of severe anxiety and sweating during work presentations, worsening over the past 1 year and impacting his work. He does not have similar symptoms in other situations. Which treatment option is most suitable?
questions.solution:
This patient complaining of severe anxiety before giving presentations is likely suffering from performance anxiety and is managed by taking propranolol shortly before the triggering situation.

Performance anxiety is a type of social anxiety that is restricted to performing or speaking in public. It is characterised by marked fear or anxiety of possible scrutiny by others. These situations are avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety. The anxiety is persistent, causing impairment in functioning and typically lasts for 6 months or more.

The treatment of performance anxiety involves the use of beta-adrenergic receptor antagonists such as propranolol or atenolol shortly before exposure to a phobic stimulus. Another option is a relatively short or intermediate-acting benzodiazepine, such as lorazepam or alprazolam. Cognitive, behavioral, and exposure techniques are also useful.

Other options : 

Option B: Buspirone is an anxiolytic medication used for long-term management of general anxiety disorder. The therapeutic action of buspirone is slow and not appropriate for performance anxiety. 

Option C: Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. Short or intermediate-acting benzodiazepines are indicated for performance anxiety.

Option D: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, which is not indicated to manage performance anxiety.

questions.text: A 21-year-old previously healthy athlete suffers a sudden cardiac arrest while playing a sport. On autopsy, it was found that there was hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The gene encoding for which of the following proteins is most commonly mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The gene encoding for β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC) proteins is most commonly mutated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

HCM is a common autosomal dominant disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy, abnormal diastolic filling (with preserved systolic function), and intermittent left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. It is the leading cause of unexplained left ventricular hypertrophy.

It is caused by mutations in genes that encode sarcomeric proteins, including myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7). It can also rarely occur due to mutations in genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT, and α-tropomyosin.

In HCM, myocardial hypertrophy occurs without ventricular dilation. Furthermore, there is asymmetric septal hypertrophy, where the ventricular septum is disproportionately thickened compared to the left ventricular free wall. The enlarged septum bulges into the ventricular cavity, giving it a banana-like shape. Hypertrophy is most marked in the subaortic region of the septum.

The most important histologic features in HCM are:

  • Massive myocyte hypertrophy
  • Myofiber disarray including that of myocyte bundles, individual myocytes, and contractile elements
  • Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries
  • Interstitial and replacement fibrosis

The images below show normal cardiac myocytes and myofibril disarray in HCM, respectively:

 

Exertional dyspnea due to reduced cardiac output is seen, and a harsh systolic ejection murmur caused due to LVOT obstruction can be heard. Further, atrial fibrillation, stroke due to mural thrombus formation, and ventricular arrhythmias are common complications of HCM. 

β-adrenergic blockers can be used to decrease heart rate and contractility, and implantable cardioverter defibrillators are used for patients with ventricular arrhythmias.

Other options:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) occurs due to truncating mutations in the titin gene. The heart in DCM is flabby and hypo-contracting, in contrast with the thick-walled, heavy, and hyper-contracting heart in HCM. Histology reveals hypertrophied myocytes with hyperchromatic distorted nuclei with a ninja star-like appearance, as shown in the image below. Variable degrees of interstitial and endocardial fibrosis is also present.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder that occurs due to mutations of genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins. It typically manifests as right-sided heart failure and can cause sudden cardiac death. Histology shows loss of myocytes, fatty infiltration, and focal fibrosis.

Option D: HCM occurs due to mutations in the gene encoding α-tropomyosin. However, this is rare, and HCM occurs most commonly due to mutations in genes encoding myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) and β-MHC (MYH7).

Related Pearl: One-liners on Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy
  • Diastolic dysfunction
  • Systolic function normal
  • On Echocardiography:

    2. Systolic anterior motion of left leaflet
    3. Banana shaped left ventricle

questions.text: A HIV patient presents with headache and fever. CSF analysis reveals lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and India ink stain finding as shown. After induction phase, what medication should be started for the maintenance phase of treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario a HIV patient with headache and fever and the presence of lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and positive india ink stain are suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis. Amphotericin B plus flucytosine is the treatment of choice in the induction phase, followed by fluconazole in the maintenance phase.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.

The diagnosis is made by the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with Indian ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination. India ink is a type of negative stain that is not picked up by the capsule, making it evident. 2 weeks of induction therapy with amphotericin B with flucytosine (Option B and C), which is followed by oral fluconazole as maintainance treatment is the standard of care.

Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.

Other options:

Option D: Echinocandins such as caspofungin and micafungin are not effective against Cryptococcus species.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with postprandial epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting. CT angiography revealed the compression of the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 35-year-old female patient presenting with postprandial epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting with CT angiography revealing compression of the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament is suggestive of Dunbar syndrome.

Dunbar syndrome/ median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS) is a vascular compression syndrome.

The celiac axis usually arises from the abdominal aorta between T11-L1, but this can vary greatly and the diaphragmatic crura arises from L1-L4. The median arcuate ligament is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the diaphragmatic crura anteriorly to the aortic hiatus. A lower diaphragmatic crura insertion or a higher celiac artery origin is likely to cause MALS. Sometimes median arcuate ligament crosses the lower abdominal aorta causing compression.

It is more common in females in the 3rd to 5th decade of life. Symptoms include postprandial symptoms including pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and unexplained weight loss.

CT angiography (CTA) aids in the diagnosis by enabling the visualization of the compressed celiac artery in 3D. Duplex ultrasonography can also be performed, but it is operator-dependent.

Treatment aims to decompress the celiac trunk using open, laparoscopic, or robotic methods in addition to adjuvant interventional procedures such as stenting and percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA).

Other options:

Option A: Wilkie syndrome is associated with obstruction of the 3rd part of the duodenum due to the decreased angle between the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the aorta. 

Option B: May Thurner syndrome is associated with compression of the left iliac vein at the point where the right iliac artery crosses over it. It results in the development of iliofemoral deep venous thrombosis (DVT).

Option C: Nutcracker syndrome occurs due to compression of the left renal vein, between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery. It presents with varicoceles and hematuria.

questions.text: A new screening test is being developed for a disease and is tested in two different states. State A has a 75% prevalence of the disease and State B has a 25% prevalence of the disease. Choose the correct statement.

choices.text: The positive predictive value of the test will be higher in State A
The negative predictive value of the test will be lower in State B
The positive predictive value of the test will be lower in State A
The negative predictive value of the test will be higher in State A

questions.solution:
The positive predictive value (PPV) of a screening test increases where the prevalence of the disease is higher, ie, in this case, PPV will be higher in State A.

In contrast, the negative predictive value (NPV) of a screening test increases where the prevalence of the disease is lower, ie, in this case, NPV will be higher in State B.

PPV is defined as the probability that a person who tests positive for a disease, actually has the disease, ie, is a true positive. Therefore, if a disease is highly prevalent in an area, and someone from that area tests positive for the disease, the chances this person actually has the disease would be higher.

NPV is defined as the probability that a person who tests negative for a disease, actually does not have the disease, ie, is a true negative. Therefore, is a disease has low prevalence in an area, and someone from that area tests negative for the disease, the chances this person actually does not have the disease would be higher.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old male comes for a routine exam and enquires about vaccines required for him. What would you recommend to him?

PCV - Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
PPSV - Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine

choices.text: PCV 13 followed by PPSV 23 after 1 year
PPSV 23 followed by PCV 13 after 1 year

questions.solution:
For a patient who is over 65 years, vaccination with both PCV 13 and PPSV 23 is indicated for adequate immunoprotection. 

Pneumococcal vaccines include:

  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV): 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23)

The Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13: It includes purified capsular polysaccharides of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. Both PCV10 and PCV13 are preservative-free and their recommended storage temperature is 2-8°C. The vaccine must not be frozen.

WHO recommends 3 primary doses or 2 primary doses plus one booster of the PCV vaccine. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9-12 months.

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23: It contains polysaccharide antigens from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria and is available for adults and children over 2 years of age. Children under 2 years of age and immunocompromised individuals do not respond well to the vaccine. It is recommended for selected groups such as:

  • Post splenectomy
  • Patients older than 65 years
  • Sickle-cell disease
  • Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney
  • Generalized malignancies
  • Organ transplants
  • Cochlear implants
  • Chronic CSF leaks

PPSV 23 is usually given a year after giving PCV 13.

questions.text: A 56-year-old alcoholic man presents with abdominal distension and pain. His temperature is 103 F. Ascitic fluid is tapped and the growth on Mac Conkey agar after 12 hours is shown below. What is the likely cause of infection?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of ascites with pain and fever with growth of lactose-fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar suggests a diagnosis of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis by Escherichia coli. 

Most cases of SBP secondary to ascites is believed to be caused by translocation of the gut bacteria via the hematogenous spread, E coli is the most commonly isolated organism.

questions.text: A new resident doctor administers anesthetic in the case of brain tumor surgery. A rise in intracranial pressure is seen. Which of the following anesthetic might be implicated?
questions.solution:

Other options

Propofol is an IV anesthetic causing pain on injection. It however doesn't cause a rise in ICT.

questions.text:
With respect to the clinical stages of acne formation, arrange the following in the correct sequence.
  1. Cyst
  2. Pustule
  3. Whitehead
  4. Papule
  5. Blackhead
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, the most likely sequence of events is Blackheads → Whiteheads → Papules → Pustules → Nodules/cyst. While blackheads and whiteheads can be seen co-existing in a patient with acne vulgaris, blackheads can precede white heads and vice versa. 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit.

Comedonal lesions are the earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct and are non-inflammatory.

  • When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called closed comedones / whiteheads.
  • When the keratin plug in the pilosebaceous unit is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air and turns black, known as open comedones / blackheads.

Inflammatory changes lead to the formation of papules, which may become pustules that rupture superficially, or else spread deeper and form cystic lesions.

questions.text: The image shows a male child with an anterior abdominal wall that is flabby and thin.   The bowel contours appear obvious on inspection and on examination the scrotum is empty. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Prune Belly Syndrome.

Prune Belly Syndrome is also known as - Eagle Barrett Syndrome, Triad Syndrome, Obrinsky Syndrome, Frohlich Syndrome.

Prune Belly Triad -

  • Cryptorchidism
  • Abdominal Wall Defects
  • Genitourinary Defects

Features of Prune Belly Syndrome:

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text: You are an intern and you see a 67-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis present to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is hemodynamically stable now after the first-line management. Which of the following agents are useful in the medical treatment of variceal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Octreotide is a useful agent in treating variceal bleeding.

Octreotide is a somatostatin analog and controls variceal bleeding by

  • Reducing hepatic and azygous blood flow
  • Reducing hepatic venous wedge pressure
  • Constricting splanchnic arterioles: direct action on vascular smooth muscle.
  • Decreasing hyperdynamic circulatory syndrome of portal hypertension by inhibiting the release of contributing peptides.

Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with Vitamin K and tranexamic acid
  • Octreotide, a somatostatin analog or terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

Ultimately, liver transplantation is the only way to definitively treat portal hypertension and variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient who is under mechanical positive pressure ventilation developed a sudden drop in saturation. BP is 90/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, and pulse rate is 120 bpm. The chest x-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis and the immediate step of management for this patient?

choices.text: Right-sided tension pneumothorax; Chest tube insertion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray points to a diagnosis of left-sided tension pneumothorax. Immediate needle thoracostomy with a wide-bore needle in the fifth intercostal space should be done in order to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

The given x-ray features showing a well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side with tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side, along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed while waiting for radiological confirmation. Imaging modalities used are ultrasound–extended focused assessment with sonar for trauma (eFAST), chest x-ray, and spiral CT.

A tension pneumothorax develops when there is a tear either in the parietal or visceral pleura. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters from the lung or chest wall through it during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration. This ultimately leads to the collapse of the affected lung.

It usually occurs following penetrating or blunt chest trauma, iatrogenic lung injury, or mechanical positive pressure ventilation.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness)
  • Neck vein distension
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury 
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side

Management of tension pneumothorax:

  • Immediate management- needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • Definitive management- tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety, identified as a triangle that lies anterior to the mid-axillary line above the nipple, below, and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

The x-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side.

Other options:

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the presence of hypotension, distended jugular veins, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad). The breath sounds are absent in tension pneumothorax while they are present in cardiac tamponade. Pericardiocentesis is done in cases of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you expect in a patient admitted for psychogenic polydipsia?
questions.solution:
A patient with psychogenic polydipsia will likely have a euvolemic hyponatremia, with a low serum and urine osmolality.

Psychogenic polydipsia is a non-osmotic disorder characterized by excessive water intake that is not driven by thirst or a true fluid deficit. This results in dilution of the extracellular fluid and hyponatremia.

In psychogenic polydipsia, the serum osmolality is low, reflecting the diluted extracellular fluid. The urine sodium is also low, as the kidneys are attempting to excrete excess water. However, the urine osmolality is also low, indicating that the kidneys are not effectively concentrating urine. This is because the excessive water intake has suppressed the production of ADH, which is necessary for the kidneys to concentrate urine.

Types of hyponatremia:

Hypovolemic hyponatremia, patients have a volume deficit due to loss of fluids rich in sodium. There is volume depletion but the depletion of sodium is relatively more than the depletion of water. This may be due to extra-renal or renal causes.In the case of extra-renal causes, there is hypovolemia due to fluid loss in conditions such as diarrhoea, vomiting, burns, etc. due to which sodium is lost along with the fluid and hence urine sodium concentration will also be low. However, in case of renal loss, the sodium is lost at the nephron level itself, causing increased urine sodium concentration, as seen in adrenal insufficiency.
Euvolemic hyponatremia, there is no volume depletion, but low sodium concentration relative to the total body water, as seen in conditions such as hypothyroidism and SIADH.
Hypervolemic hyponatremia, patients are in a condition of fluid overload. In case of fluid overload due to acute or chronic renal failure, urine sodium concentration will be high. 
In case of fluid overload due to cirrhosis, CCF and nephrotic syndrome, urine sodium concentration will be low.

Other options:

Option A. Hypovolemia, SOsm <275 mOsm/kg, UNa < 40 mEq/L:

This describes a patient with hypovolemic hyponatremia. The low SOsm reflects the diluted extracellular fluid and the low UNa indicates that the kidneys are trying to conserve sodium, which is a compensatory mechanism in response to hypovolemia. Possible causes of this presentation include non renal salt losses: severe vomiting, diarrhea and dehydration.

Option C. Euvolemia, SOsm <275 mOsm/kg, UOsm > 100 mOSm/kg

This option describes a patient with euvolemic hyponatremia. The low SOsm reflects diluted serum due to excess reabsorption. However, the high UOsm indicates that the kidneys are able to concentrate urine, which suggests that the hyponatremia is not due to a problem with the kidneys' ability to conserve water. This is seen in SIADH.

Option D: Hypervolemia, SOsm <275 mOsm/kg, UNa <25 mEq/L:

This option describes a patient with hypervolemic hyponatremia. The low SOsm reflects the diluted ECF. The low UNa indicates that the kidneys are trying to conserve sodium, which is a compensatory mechanism in response to hypervolemia. Possible causes of this presentation include: Heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: The total pulmonary vascular resistance of the lung is lowest at which lung volume?
questions.solution:
The total pulmonary vascular resistance is lowest at Functional residual capacity. 

The influence of lung volume on pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) is mediated through its impact on alveolar capillaries.  At the beginning of expiration(end of inspiration), the air-filled alveoli exert pressure on the alveolar capillaries, resulting in an elevation of pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR).   Unlike the capillary beds in systemic circulation, the capillary beds in the lungs make up 2/5th of the pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR).   During end inspiration, the diameters of the bigger extra-alveolar arteries grow due to radial traction and elastic rebound. Additionally, the pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) of these veins decreases as lung capacity increases.   During exhalation, the alveoli that have emptied offer less resistance to the capillaries within them, resulting in a decrease in their pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR). On the other hand, the increased pressure in the pleural space during exhalation causes an increase in the PVR of the blood vessels outside the alveoli. Due to the contrasting impacts of lung volume on pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), the overall PVR in the lung is at its minimum during functional residual capacity (FRC).

The graph below shows the variation of the total pulmonary vascular resistance of the lung with various lung volumes as described.

questions.text: A newborn delivered with forceps presents with a diffuse fluctuant head mass that crosses suture lines. The newborn is lethargic and is found to be in hypovolemic shock. Where is the location of fluid accumulation in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Between periosteum of skull bone and bone

questions.solution:
The newborn delivered with forceps, presenting with a diffuse fluctuant head mass crossing suture lines, and hypovolemic shock most likely has a subgaleal hemorrhage which is characterized by accumulation of blood in the subgaleal space between galea aponeurotica and periosteum of the skull bone.

The area under galea aponeurotica is a large potential space, thus bleeding can be extensive. It occurs as a result of ventouse or forceps deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connects the dural venous sinuses with the superficial veins of the scalp. It can also occur in hereditary coagulopathies such as hemophilia and in association with skull fractures.

A subgaleal hemorrhage presents as a fluctuant mass that crosses cranial sutures or fontanels and increases in size after birth. The presence of fluctuance early on, is an important distinguishing feature of subgaleal hemorrhage. Newborns should be monitored for hypotension, anemia, and hyperbilirubinemia. Treatment is symptomatic by correction of hypovolemia and it typically resolves over 2-3 weeks.

Other options : 

Option A: Caput succedaneum is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp, involving the presenting part in a vertex delivery. It may extend across the midline and crosses suture lines. It is not associated with life threatening hypovolemic shock.

Option B: Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage that is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. There is no discoloration of the overlying scalp.

Option D: Epidural hemorrhages, usually traumatic in origin, are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or occur as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no complications.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with GERD has no improvement after long-term medical therapy. He underwent surgical treatment for GERD. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure in the given image shows a 360-degree wrap, which is known as Nissen's fundoplication; this procedure is done for GERD. Nissen's fundoplication is a complete fundoplication procedure.

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus. In the Nissen's fundoplication procedure, the fundus is wrapped the entire 360 degrees around the esophagus. 

The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is the gas-bloat syndrome. In this condition, patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the oesophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach, resulting in a bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence.

Other options:

Option A: The toupet procedure is the re-creation of a sphincter around the EGJ done by wrapping the fundus around the oesophagus. A posterior 180-270-degree wrap is used.

Option B: The Dor procedure is fundoplication, most commonly used in the setting of the esophagal myotomy. It consists of an anterior 180-degree wrap.

Option C: Watson's fundoplication is a 90-degree anterior fundoplication. It is reported to achieve good reflux control while permitting burping and active vomiting and reducing gas bloat.

questions.text: Name the condition for which the incision A is made in the image below
questions.solution:
The above incision is a circumferential incision used to relieve acute suppurative otitis media. This incision is made in the posteroinferior tympanic membrane to avoid injury to the incudo-stapedial joint. 

A radial incision is incision B made to allow suction of a serous otitis media. 

Myringotomy refers to the incision made on the tympanic membrane with the purpose to drain suppurative or nonsuppurative effusion of the middle ear or to provide aeration in case of a malfunctioning eustachian tube.

Indications of myringotomy:

  • Acute suppurative otitis media and its complications
  • Recurrent acute otitis media
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the Eustachian tube)
  • Atelectatic ear (treated along with grommet insertion)

Contraindication of myringotomy: It is contraindicated in suspected cases of intratympanic glomus tumor, as it can cause profuse bleeding in such patients.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with low backache and significant weight loss for one year. On rectal examination, a palpable mass is noted. MRI reveals the presence of destructive lesions in the sacral region arising from notochordal remnants. What characteristic feature is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a 60-year-old man presenting with low backache and significant weight loss for one year, a palpable mass on rectal examination and MRI revealing the presence of destructive lesions in the sacral region arising from notochordal remnants is suggestive of chordoma. Physaliferous cells are characteristic cells seen on microscopy.

These cells contain abundant vacuolated cytoplasm and are arranged in long strands or chords in a mucinous background.

Chordomas are malignant bone tumours derived from remnant embryonic tissue of the notochord and are typically found in the axial midline. It is the most common primary malignancy of the sacrum. 50% of chordomas develop in the sacrococcygeal region, with more than 30% developing at the base of the skull. The remainder are scattered throughout the spine. Peak incidence is seen in the 5th to 7th decades of life.

Low back pain is the most common presenting symptom in patients with sacrococcygeal tumours. They can also present with bowel and bladder dysfunction and sciatic pain. Rectal examination reveals a palpable mass.

Radiographically, chordomas appear as destructive lesions. Since sacrococcygeal lesions can be obstructed by bowel gas, a lateral X-ray or MRI is used in diagnosis.

The image given below shows an MRI of a chordoma.

Wide margin surgical resection is the mainstay treatment, even if it results in a neurologic deficit because progressive tumour growth would inevitably lead to a neurologic deficit and potentially metastatic disease. Additionally, patients for whom resection is not practical may benefit from radiation therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Storiform pattern of cells is characteristic of malignant fibrous histiocytoma. Microscopy shows pleomorphic and bizarre tumour cells with foamy cytoplasm and marked atypia in the background of the inflamed collagenous stroma. They can occur at any age excluding the 1st decade and are commonly seen in the metaphysics of the distal femur or the proximal tibia. They do not arise from notochordal remnants.

Option B: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumour of childhood. It is most commonly seen in ages 10-20 years.  It is most commonly seen at the epiphyses, usually at the ends of long bones. Microscopically chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix with the presence of "chicken wire calcification", which is pathognomic.

Option D: Chondrosarcomas are slow-growing tumours that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone derived from enchondral ossification. It can present between the 3rd-8th decade of life. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumours with irregular granular calcifications giving a 'honeycomb' or 'popcorn' appearance.

The below radiograph shows popcorn calcification in chondrosarcoma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with abdominal pain. He gives a history of weight loss for 3 months. Barium enema shows the following picture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is this patient is carcinoma colon.

The above clinical scenario of abdominal pain with weight loss and given image showing the 'apple core appearance' in barium enema which is characteristic of carcinoma colon. 

Colon carcinoma typically arises in patients above the age group of 50 years. It arises from the adenomatous polyps after a mutation sequence of adenoma-carcinoma influenced by environmental factors. Most colon cancers occur in the left colon.

The clinical features of colon carcinoma include a change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding in cases of left-sided colon tumors and iron deficiency anemia or a mass in proximal lesions of the colon.

Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice in suspected colorectal carcinoma. Double-contrast barium enema shows a constant irregular filling defect known as the apple core appearance. Computed tomography (CT) virtual colonoscopy has replaced barium enema as it is highly sensitive. Spiral CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis is now the standard means for staging colon cancer. 

Other options:

Option B- On barium enema, ileocecal tuberculosis shows narrowing of the terminal ileum, thickening and gaping of the ileocecal valve, thickening and hypermotility of the caecum.

Below is the barium enema showing ileocecal tuberculosis with the yellow arrow indicating the shrunken caecum, the red arrow indicating stricturing and narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction and the blue arrow indicating proximal ileal dilatation.

questions.text: Where does trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole act respectively in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole act at sites 2 and 1 respectively in the given image.

Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase (1) that converts para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) to dihydrofolate. Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase (2). Dihydrofolate reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. Both these enzymes are essential for the synthesis of folic acid in a bacterial cell. Inhibition of folic acid synthesis will cause disruption of basic metabolic functions in the microbe leading to its death.

Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of 1:5. Sulfamethoxazole is an intermediate-acting sulfonamide with a plasma half-life of around 10 hours. Trimethoprim also has a similar plasma half-life and therefore combined with sulfamethoxazole. 

Co-trimoxazole is used to treat urinary tract infections, and respiratory tract infections against organisms like gram-positive cocci, Hemophilus influenza, and Moraxella catarrhalis. It is also used against severe infections of E. coli, Shigella, non-typhoid Salmonella, and Yersinia enterocolitica. High doses of Co-trimoxazole are used in neutropenic and AIDS patients against Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, and megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency. Trimethoprim is teratogenic as it inhibits folate synthesis. It should be used with caution in renal failure patients.

Other options:
Option C: 3 indicates cell wall inhibitors that include drugs like Vancomycin, Bacitracin, Penicillins, Cephalosporins, Carbapenems, and Monobactams. 6 represents fluoroquinolones which inhibit DNA gyrase.
 
Option D: 4 and 5 are protein synthesis inhibitors specifically inhibiting 30s and 50s subunits of the ribosomes. 30s inhibitors (4) include Aminoglycosides and Tetracyclines. 50s inhibitors (5) include Macrolides, Linezolid, Clindamycin, and Chloramphenicol.
