questions.text: A person did not consume food for more than 72 hours during a protest. Which of the following mechanisms provides energy in this case?
questions.solution:
In a person starving for more than 72 hours, the source of energy is starvation ketogenesis.

In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

The first stage of fasting: The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting, which is 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

The second stage of fasting: Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days. Substrates for gluconeogenesis are glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

The third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon: insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. 

The final stage of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin. Hence glucagon: insulin ratio is increased.

Effects of increased glucagon: insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  1. It activates glycogen phosphorylase, the key enzyme of glycogenolysis, and deactivates glycogen synthase. This causes a rapid mobilization of liver glycogen stores to be utilized as fuel.
  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependant on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with a sudden increase in the lesions given in the image. Which of the following should be suspected?
questions.solution:
The finding seen in the case scenario provided is seborrheic keratosis and this is highly suggestive of a visceral malignancy.

A sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses in association with skin tags and acanthosis nigricans has been associated with a variety of malignancies, including gastrointestinal and lung cancers; it is also known as the Leser-Trélat sign.

Seborrheic keratoses are common epidermal tumors consisting of a benign proliferation of immature keratinocytes. They present as well-demarcated, round or oval lesions with a dull, verrucous surface and a typical stuck-on appearance.

questions.text: During your ward rounds, you observe a child with the abnormality seen in the image below. Which of the following risk factors would you suspect to be involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The image depicts caudal regression syndrome, which is associated with both overt and gestational diabetes mellitus in the mother.

This syndrome consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and/or the lumbar vertebrae. It occurs more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers (both preconceptionally and early in pregnancy) than in other infants although the exact mechanism is unclear. 

USG shows an abnormally short spine lacking normal lumbosacral curvature ending abruptly above the level of the iliac wings. The iliac wings appear abnormally close to each other like a shield due to the absence of the sacral vertebra. There may be associated VACTREL anomalies as well.

Other options:

  • Folic acid deficiency either as a result of dietary deficiency or due to antifolate drugs is associated with neural tube defects such as myelomeningocele, cardiac defects, and oral clefts.
  • Maternal use of lithium leads to an Ebstein anomaly and macrosomia. Chest X-ray showing a box-shaped heart in Ebstein anomaly is shown below: 
  • Maternal use of phenytoin causes fetal hydantoin syndrome characterized by digital hypoplasia, microcephaly, oral clefts, and other craniofacial abnormalities.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of structures pierced during a lumbar puncture after skin and subcutaneous fat?
  1. Ligamentum flavum
  2. Posterior longitudinal ligament
  3. Supraspinous ligaments
  4. Interspinous ligament
  5. Arachnoid mater
  6. Dura mater
questions.solution:
Lumbar puncture is a diagnostic procedure done to obtain a sample of cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space. The following structures are pierced during lumbar puncture, in that order:

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Epidural space
  • Dura
  • Arachnoid
  • Subarachnoid space 

The posterior longitudinal ligament is not pierced during a lumbar puncture. (Options A, C, and D)


Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a common post-procedure symptom. It occurs due to loss of CSF through the dura which causes traction on the pain-sensitive intracranial structures. The headache in PDPH is typically frontal or occipital. It is aggravated with the upright or sitting posture and is relieved by lying supine. 

Other complications include infections, bleeding, cerebral herniation, and radicular pain.

 

Spotting that the posterior longitudinal ligament which is not pierced during lumbar puncture could help solve the question quicker by ruling out the other options.

questions.text: A man presents with blistering shortly after consuming alcohol at a party. He notes that this has occurred several times in the past. The lesions are shown below. What is the most likely enzyme affected in his conditon?
questions.solution:
The image given above is of porphyria cutanea tarda: erosions, blisters, pigmentary changes, and scarring. Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the commonest porphyria, as is likely in the case of blistering following alcohol consumption. It results from the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD). This causes an accumulation of uroporphyrin and other highly carboxylated porphyrins. It is usually acquired (75%, sporadic) and is often associated with liver disease. It does not cause acute attacks. 

Patients notice increased fragility on light‐exposed skin, particularly the backs of the hands and forearms, with minor trauma shearing the skin away to leave sharply marginated erosions that crust and resolve over few weeks leaving atrophic scars, milia, and often mottled hyper‐ or hypopigmentation. Hypertrichosis on the upper face and forehead is common

Pink or coral-red fluorescence of urine is seen under Wood's light.

The classification of porphyrias based on their enzyme deficiencies is as shown below:

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase: Acute intermittent porphyria

questions.text: All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except that :

choices.text: It is a purely motor nerve
It arises mainly from C4 spinal nerve
It is formed at the lateral border of scalenus anterior
The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about the phrenic nerve except option A as it is a mixed nerve (sensory and motor nerve).

Each phrenic nerve provides the sole motor supply to its hemidiaphragm. In its thoracic course, each phrenic nerve supplies sensory branches to the mediastinal pleura, fibrous pericardium, and parietal serous pericardium.

The phrenic nerve is a mixed nerve derived mostly from the C4 ramus and also receives contributions from the C3 and C5 ventral rami.

It is formed at the lateral border of the scalenus anterior. At the root of the neck, the right phrenic nerve runs anterior to the second part of the right subclavian artery from which it is separated by scalenus anterior muscle. The phrenic nerve lies posterior to the right subclavian vein.

The right phrenic nerve is shorter and more vertical than the left. The right phrenic nerve passes through the vena caval opening. The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm just anterior to the central tendon.

The phrenic nerve is responsible for the referred pain which usually occurs when there is inflammation of the diaphragmatic pleura, e.g. in basal pneumonia, pleural effusions, or with irritation of the peritoneal pleura, as with a subphrenic abscess. It is frequently felt at the tip of the shoulder due to the common root of origin of the phrenic nerve and the nerves supplying the shoulder.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the epiploic foramen and worried she might have injured the structures around it. All are true about the boundaries of the epiploic foramen except:

choices.text: Posteriorly -  Aorta and origin of celiac trunk

questions.solution:
Posterior relation of epiploic foramen does not include aorta and origin of celiac trunk.

Epiploic foramen is posteriorly related to inferior vena cava, right suprarenal gland, and body of T12 vertebra. Commencement of abdominal aorta and celiac trunk forms posterior relation of the lesser sac and not of Epiploic foramen. 

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow or aditus to the lesser sac) is a short vertical slit situated behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.

Boundaries of epiploic foramen are:

  • Posterior – Body of T12 vertebra, Inferior vena cava, right adrenal gland.
  • Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver.
  • Inferior – First part of the duodenum and the horizontal part of the hepatic artery.

questions.text: A 43-year-old diabetic woman notices that on the extension of her fingers, the middle finger requires extra force to extend and snaps while doing so. There is an audible click when the finger is flexed. The extension is as depicted below. This is caused due to the involvement of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the video is a trigger finger which involves the flexor tendon.

Trigger finger is caused by stenosing tenosynovitis of the flexor sheath. There is nodular or fusiform swelling on the flexor tendon that prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. When the finger is flexed or extended, the nodular swelling passes through the A1 pulley with a snap, leading to a triggering effect. The nodule can get trapped behind the A1 pulley leading to a locking of the finger in flexion.

Surgical treatment involves the release of the A1 pulley, which is thickened and fibrosed. Early cases may be treated with a steroid injection into the tendon sheath.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented to you with fatigue for a month. She has eosinophilia and megaloblastic anemia as per her reports. A parasitic infestation is suspected. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with features of fatigue and megaloblastic anemia suggests a vitamin B12 deficiency. This along with eosinophilia indicates a worm infestation most likely Diphyllobothrium latum which is due to consumption of undercooked freshwater fish. 

The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to vitamin B12 deficiency. This can also lead to megaloblastic anemia.

The first intermediate host is a freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is a freshwater fish. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called an oncosphere.

The pernicious anemia caused by the infection is called bothriocephalus anaemia.

Treatment is praziquantel in a single dose of 10 mg/kg. In severe B12 deficiency, parenteral vitamin B12 should be given.

questions.text: A patient was started on evolocumab for the treatment of familial hypercholesterolemia. What is the primary mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody used to decrease elevated serum LDL levels by inhibiting PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9), a protease that degrades LDL receptors on hepatocytes.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors, the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially  Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age. Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >300 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Homozygotes for the disease might have total serum cholesterol even up to 1000 mg/dL. 

Treatment includes restriction of saturated and trans fats in the diet and high-intensity statin therapy. If adequate control is not achieved with statins alone, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor (Ezetimibe) or a PCSK9 inhibitor (Alirocumab, Evolocumab) can be added to the treatment. 

Other options:

Option B: Statins decrease LDL cholesterol synthesis by inhibiting activity of HMG-CoA reductase.

Option C and D: Ezetimibe interferes with a specific cholesterol transport protein NPC1L1 in the intestinal mucosa and reduces the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol. Bile acid sequestrants such as cholestyramine binds bile acids in the intestine and also decrease their reabsorption.

questions.text: A middle aged patient presents with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for the last two months. He also gives a history of arthralgia involving multiple joints for the last two years and an intestinal biopsy with staining is shown below. What is the likely cause for the biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Whipples disease is caused by accumulaton of Trophyrema whipplei, a gram positive bacillus. The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease. Amongst the given options, the best-suited treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.  Prolonged antibiotics are recommended but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus, Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

questions.text: A 25-year-old contact lens user presents with complaints of mucopurulent discharge from his left eye associated with photophobia. Slit-lamp examination of his tarsal conjunctiva shows circular red elevations with apical infiltrates. Which of the following term is used to describe this slip lamp finding?
questions.solution:
The term 'papillae' is used to describe the abovesaid slit-lamp finding.

The presence of papillae is one of the clinical signs of conjunctivitis. It has the following features

  • They are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium. Hence, they appear as red elevations.
  • Infiltrates represent the cells recruited to the site of inflammation, and they typically accompany a papillary response.
  • Size less than 1mm is macropapilla; whereas the size of greater than 1mm is the giant papilla.
  • Causes for this include bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, chronic blepharitis, and wearing contact lenses.

Follicles: They are multiple, discrete, yellowish-white, round elevations, 1-2 mm in diameter. They are due to localised aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. Follicles are most prominent in the fornices. The common causes are viral and chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Chemosis: It is used to describe the conjunctival oedema

Granulomas: They are fleshy sessile or pedunculated lesions with inflammatory tissue. They usually result from some form of chronic local irritation such as a foreign body. 

The following images show the papillae and follicles respectively.

questions.text: An undernourished child is brought for consultation. You prescribe a mineral supplement that is absorbed by the mechanism shown in the image below. Identify the supplement.
questions.solution:
The given image shows iron absorption and transport from a duodenal enterocyte into the blood, hence the mineral supplement prescribed can be identified as an iron supplement.

The following image shows in detail, the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte.

Dietary iron is available in two forms - heme and non-heme iron. Initially, the ferric non-heme iron is reduced to ferrous iron by duodenal cytochrome B (ferric reductase) or by vitamin C. The reduced ferrous iron is then transferred into the enterocyte by DMT 1 (divalent metal transporter). 

Heme iron moves into the cytoplasm with the help of transporters. Here, it is metabolized to release ferrous iron, which then follows the same pathway as non-heme iron.

Once inside the enterocyte, it can either get stored as ferritin or transferred across the basolateral membrane by ferroportin. In the plasma, iron is transported in the Fe3+ form bound to transferrin, which is a transport protein. Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+ before it is transported.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby iron absorption too. Thus, iron is trapped in the intestinal cells which is eventually sloughed off. Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from macrophages by binding to ferroportin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

questions.text: A young female patient with a recent travel history comes to the OPD with a history of prolonged abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern. On examination, faint, salmon-colored macules are seen on the trunk. A serological test is used to confirm the diagnosis. This test is an example of
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of enteric fever/ typhoid fever. Widal test is an agglutination test done in case of typhoid fever.

Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. The clinical course may vary from mild undifferentiated pyrexia to a rapidly fatal disease. Clinical manifestations include malaise, step ladder pyrexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and myalgia. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen that fade on pressure. They appear in the second week and are seen as shown below

Widal test:

It is a type of tube agglutination test in which, H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli are measured in the serum sample. It is performed by mixing equal volumes (0.4 ml) of serial dilutions of the serum (from 1/10 to 1/640) with fixed volumes of H and O antigens in the Dreyer's and Felix agglutination tubes, respectively. These tubes are incubated overnight and the agglutination titres are read. H agglutination leads to the formation of cotton woolly clumps while O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube.

Interpretation of Widal test: 

  • Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
  • H agglutinin titer > 1/640 and O agglutinin titer >1/320 is considered significant.

Other options

  • Option b: In tube flocculation test, serial dilutions of the toxin/ toxoid are added to tubes containing a fixed quantity of antitoxin. The amount of toxin or toxoid that flocculates optimally with one unit of the antitoxin is defined as Lf dose. Example: Kahn test for syphilis.
  • Option c: In slide flocculation test, a drop each of the antigen and antiserum are placed on the slide and mixed by shaking; appearance of floccules is taken as positive. Eg. VDRL test for syphilis
  • Option d: In Ring precipitation test, antigen solution is layered over a column of antiserum in a narrow tube. the precipitate is formed at the junction of the 2 liquids. Example: Ascoli’s thermoprecipitin test for detection of anthrax antigen.

Tube flocculation, slide flocculation and ring precipitation test are all types of precipitation tests.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with no comorbidities presents for a routine physical examination. His father and paternal grandmother were diagnosed with colon cancer at ages 54 and 58, respectively. When should he start colonoscopy screening?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is colonoscopy at age 40.

The patient's family history of colon cancer increases his risk of developing the disease. The current recommendation is that individuals with a first-degree relative diagnosed with colon cancer before age 60 should start colonoscopy screening 10 years earlier than the age at which their relative was diagnosed. In this case, the patient's father was diagnosed with colon cancer at age 54, so the patient should start screening at age 40.

Risk Category Recommended Screening Interval Recommended Screening Test(s)
Average risk

Starting at age 50, every 10 years

(NOTE: latest guidelines suggest age 45)

 Colonoscopy, CT colonography, flexible sigmoidoscopy with FIT, FIT or stool DNA test every 2 years

Increased risk:

A. Single first degree relative with CRC >60 years

B. Single first degree relative with CRC <60 years/ TWO first degree relatives with CRC at any age

Starting at age 40 or 10 years earlier than the age at which the youngest relative was diagnosed, whichever comes first.

In case of A. Repeat every 10 years

In case of B: Every 5 years

 Colonoscopy every 5-10 years, CT colonography every 5 years, flexible sigmoidoscopy with FIT every 5 years, FIT or stool DNA test every year
High risk Starting at age 20-25 or earlier Colonoscopy every 1-3 years, CT colonography every 1-2 years, flexible sigmoidoscopy with FIT every 1-2 years

The patient should be informed of his increased risk for colon cancer and advised to start colonoscopy screening at age 40. He should also be counseled on other risk factors for colon cancer and encouraged to adopt a healthy lifestyle, including a diet high in fiber and low in red meat and processed foods, regular exercise, and smoking cessation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of cough, increased thirst, and increased urination.Chest X-ray revealed a central mass arising in the right lung field.  After the initial workup, he is diagnosed to have the paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). FNAC of the tumor is done as shown. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient presents with the following cataract. He also has gonadal atrophy and frontal balding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a Christmas tree cataract. This in addition to his clinical findings of gonadal atrophy and frontal balding points to a diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy. It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder. 

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused due to CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

Option A: Atopic dermatitis presents with a shield shaped cataract. 

Option B: Wilson's disease presents with a sunflower shaped cataract along with the characteristic Kayser-Fleischer ring

Option C: Diabetes mellitus causes a snowflake cataract.

questions.text: A young woman presented with mood disturbance, tearfulness, and a lack of energy on the 5th day of postpartum. She was counseled and educated about postpartum blues. She should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last longer than:
questions.solution:
The patient should be evaluated for postpartum depression if her symptoms last >2 weeks.

Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period. It is characterized by transient mood disturbances like a labile mood and sadness. It typically develops within one week of delivery. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth, and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood. Treatment is nothing more than education and support, however, symptoms lasting longer than 2 weeks should be evaluated for postpartum depression.

Postpartum depression is characterized by a minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation lasting for >2 weeks. It is usually seen within the 4-6 weeks. There may be associated thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby. 

Postpartum psychosis or puerperal psychosis is a psychotic disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. It is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset of 2-3 weeks postpartum although it can occur in the first few days. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by insomnia, restlessness, agitation, lability of mood, and mild cognitive deficits. The treatment of choice involves antipsychotics and lithium, with an antidepressant. 

Postpartum delirium is characterized by fluctuating levels of awareness or attention.

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male patient previously treated for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with similar symptoms. Radio-imaging confirms a recurrence with an inaccessible intracranial extension. Which of the following treatment approaches is considered now?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is considered for recurrent inaccessible juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).

JNA is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. 

Patients usually present with:

  • Epistaxis (most common presentation): Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous
  • Mass: A mass may be present in either the postnasal space, resulting in progressive nasal obstruction, or nasopharynx, where it may obstruct both choanae. The mass is firm in consistency, but digital palpation of the same should not be done. If the mass obstructs the eustachian tube, conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion may be observed.
  • Proptosis, swelling of the cheeks, broadening of nasal bridge, and involvement of 2nd, 3rd, 4th and 6th cranial nerves: May occur

JNA can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and carotid angiography. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space is a characteristic CT finding of JNA. This is known as the Holman-Miller sign or antral sign, as shown in the image below.

 

Recurrence has been reported up to 35%. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery or radiotherapy when the tumor is inaccessible.

Other options:

Option A: Hormonal therapy can be used as primary or adjunctive treatment. Since it is commoner in adolescent males in their twenties, the tumor may be testosterone dependant. Therefore, hormonal therapy with diethylstilbestrol and an androgen blocker like flutamide may be considered.

Option B: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, vincristine, and dacarbazine is used in case of very aggressive recurrent tumors and residual tumors.

Option C: Endoscopic approach is not useful as the stem clearly mentions that the tumor is inaccessible.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child presents with mild diarrhea for the past 3 days. Today, he developed severe lethargy and an episode of seizures.  Laboratory testing reveals hypoketotic hypoglycemia. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes could produce this kind of test result?
questions.solution:
This child, with lethargy, seizures and hypoketotic hypoglycemia is likely to have medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Among the given options, hypoketotic hypoglycemia can be caused only by medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

Medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is the most common disorder associated with mitochondrial fatty acid beta-oxidation. It is also one of the most common inborn errors of metabolism. MCAD is an important enzyme involved in fatty acid beta-oxidation. This process is important in the production of ketone bodies as an energy source when blood glucose levels are low.

It is usually diagnosed at birth during routine screening for disorders of the newborn. However, sometimes, it can be detected within the first two years of life. 

These babies present with vomiting that progresses to lethargy and seizures, triggered by mild illness. The common laboratory results seen in these patients result from a failure to synthesize ketone bodies during episodes of hypoglycemia. Hence, the child will present with hypoketotic hypoglycemia. The diagnosis can be confirmed with a combination of biochemical and genetic testing. This illness, once diagnosed can be easily managed with small frequent meals, to avoid a state of hypoglycemia. 

Other options:

Option (B)- Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency can result in phenylketonuria. This is an inborn error of metabolism in which phenylalanine is unable to convert to tyrosine, resulting in the accumulation of phenylalanine. This results in the characteristic 'musty' odor of the urine and body fluids. These children can also present with seizures and hyperactivity. In fact, many of the symptoms result from increased phenylpyruvate (a ketoacid) derived from the buildup of phenylalanine in this condition.

Option (C)- UMP synthase is an enzyme deficiency that results in orotic aciduria. This disorder is an inborn error of pyrimidine metabolism that presents with developmental delay, failure to thrive, and possibly epilepsy. Laboratory testing reveals pancytopenia.  

Option (D)- HMG CoA reductase is an important enzyme involved in the synthesis of cholesterol. This enzyme is targeted by statins, which are prescribed in hypercholesterolemia, and in patients at risk for cardiovascular events.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the management of a dog-bite in a healthy individual?

choices.text: RIG should be administered IV within 7 days of the first vaccine dose.
Five-dose (Essen) regimen is administered IM on days 0, 3, 7, 14 and 28.
WHO prequalified vaccines are thimerosal-based vaccines for increased durability.
People with PrEP require RIG on exposure to the virus.

questions.solution:
The five-dose (Essen) regimen is administered IM on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 into the deltoid muscle of the individual.

Other options:

Option A: Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is never given IV. 

Option C: WHO prequalified rabies vaccines do not contain thimerosal. Thimerosal is a mercury-containing preservative used for its antiseptic and antifungal properties in many other vaccines but not in the rabies vaccine.

Option D: Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) of a previously immunized individual (PrEP or PEP) includes boosters on days 0 and 3, without RIG.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Histopathological examination would not reveal acantholysis in patients with:
questions.solution:
Acantholysis is not seen in bullous pemphigoid. It is seen in diseases like pemphigus, Darier's disease, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis in pemphigus vulgaris affects the lower part of the epidermis while that in pemphigus foliaceus affects the upper part. In Hailey-Hailey disease, acantholysis affects the entire thickness of the epidermis.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

  • Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholuysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:
    • Pemphigus and its variants
    • Acantholytic dermatosis
    • Darier's disease
    • Hailey Hailey disease
    • Warty dyskeratoma
  • Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:
    • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella-zoster infections (chickenpox and shingles)
    • Bullous impetigo
    • Solar keratoses

questions.text: The auscultation of an ejection systolic murmur in a child with severe anemia can be best explained due to?

choices.text: Increaseed blood viscosity, Increased blood velocity
Increased blood density, Increased blood velocity
Decreased blood density, Decreased blood velocity
Decreased blood viscosity, Increased blood velocity

questions.solution:
An ejection systolic murmur in a child with anemia or any flow murmur in anemia is caused due to reduced blood viscosity and an increase in blood velocity thus causing an increase in Reynold's number.

Anemia is characterized by a reduction in hematocrit levels, resulting in a decrease in the mass of red blood cells. Additionally, the presence of turbulent blood flow due to anemia leads to the occurrence of functional murmurs. The Reynolds number, which serves as an indicator of turbulence, is elevated in individuals with anemia as a result of reduced viscosity of the blood. Another factor contributing to the elevated Reynolds number observed in individuals with anemia is a heightened cardiac output, resulting in an augmentation of blood flow velocity.


The turbulence of flow depends upon Reynold’s number:

v – velocity of flow – cm/sec
ρ – density of blood
d – diameter of the vessel
μ – viscosity of blood in poise

Reynold’s number

Type of blood flow

<2000

Laminar

2000-3000

Transitional

>3000

Turbulent

In the proximal portions of the aorta and pulmonary artery, Reynold’s number can rise to several thousand during the rapid phase of the ejection, which causes considerable turbulence due to the following:

  • High velocity of blood flow
  • Pulsatile nature of the flow
  • Sudden change in vessel diameter
  • Large vessel diameter

Another notable clinical application of Reynold's number is the explanation of turbulence in patients with thrombi occluding the vessels which causes a constriction of the blood vessel's diameter, leading to an elevation in blood velocity at the location of the thrombus.

questions.text: A child presents for follow up for IgA nephropathy. Among the given clinical findings, which of the following would indicate a poor prognosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In patients with IgA nephropathy, persistent hypertension at follow up is indicative of poor prognosis. 

IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease) is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Clinically, children and young adults present with gross or microscopic hematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory (synpharyngitic presentation) or gastrointestinal infection.

The progression of the disease is slow and variable. There may be heavy proteinuria, hypertension and chronic renal failure in severe cases. IgA nephropathy in children is associated with an increased risk of progressive disease developing later in adulthood, prompting the need for careful long term follow up.

Indicators of poor prognosis at presentation or follow-up include persistent hypertension, decreased renal function, and significant, increasing, or prolonged proteinuria. Histologic evidence of diffuse mesangial proliferation, extensive glomerular crescents, glomerulosclerosis, and diffuse tubulointerstitial changes (such as inflammation and fibrosis) are correlated with more severe prognosis.

The below image is an immunofluorescence study of IgA nephropathy showing the characteristic IgA deposition in the mesangial regions.

The disease is treated with ACE inhibitors and ARBs to control high blood pressure and proteinuria. If ineffective, corticosteroids and immunosuppressants may be added.

Other options : 

Option B: Serum IgA levels have no diagnostic or prognostic value in IgA nephropathy because they are elevated in only 15% of pediatric patients.

Option C: Serum C3 levels in IgA nephropathy are characteristically normal, and rarely low C3 levels are seen in severe cases.

Option D: History of recurrent hematuria is common in IgA nephropathy and is not related to prognostication.

questions.text:
A woman with persistent asthma, comes to establish antenatal care after positive pregnancy test. For adequate control, her regimen was increased to daily medium dose ICS and as-needed salbutamol last month. What should she be advised regarding asthma management during pregnancy?

ICS : Inhaled corticosteroids

choices.text: Decrease dose to low dose ICS

questions.solution:
Drugs such as inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and short acting beta-2 adrenergic agonists (SABAs) are safe to use in pregnancy and can be continued without any modification.

Poor asthma control may have adverse effects on fetal development. SABAs, ICS and theophylline have been shown to be safe, and are not teratogenic. Although, safety information concerning newer classes of drugs (LABAs, antileukotriene inhibitors and anti-IgE antibodies) are lacking they are recommended for use. There is also no contraindication during breastfeeding.

Early asthma stages are well tolerated by healthy non-pregnant women but may be dangerous for pregnant women and the fetus, as the diminished functional residual capacity and greater pulmonary shunting makes the mother susceptible to hypoxia and hypoxemia. 

If the patient has daytime symptoms up to 2 times per week, and nighttime awakenings up to 2 times per month it is called intermittent asthma. If the symptoms are more severe, then the patient has persistent asthma. Persistent asthma is further classified based on symptom severity:

Category Daytime symptoms Nighttime awakening Treatment
    Mild persistent     More than 2 times per week but less than daily 3-4 times a month but not every week Low dose ICS + formoterol as needed
Moderate persistent Daily Once per week Low dose ICS + formoterol daily
Severe persistent Present throughout the day along with severe restriction of daily activities Almost every night Medium to high dose ICS + formoterol/LABA daily + add-on drugs

Inhaled corticosteroid is the first line of treatment in patients with persistent asthma. As per Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, formoterol + low-dose ICS is the preferred reliever in all cases of asthma. SABAs are alternative relievers to manage all cases of asthma.

Other options:

Option C: The dosage of ICS should be decreased if symptoms are controlled after 3 months. This patient’s dosage was recently increased 1 month ago.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2022)

Asthma management - GINA 2022

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman had an episode of tonic-clonic seizure after which she was brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient is febrile and appears slightly confused. Neurologic and physical examination findings are normal. Laboratory test results are as below, and the peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
Investigations reports:

Platelet count: 45000/mm3
Leukocyte count: 9000/mm3

aPTT: 35 seconds

Therapeutic plasma exchange is the treatment of choice for thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

The laboratory tests show anemia and thrombocytopenia. Leukocyte count, PT, and aPTT are normal. Serum creatinine is elevated. The peripheral smear shows schistocytes on the blood smear. All of these findings are suggestive of TTP.

Note that TTP is a distinct entity and not the same as ITP

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy developed a sudden onset weakness of the left side of the body with facial deviation to the right side. On examination, he was tall and thin with elongated limbs and an ocular finding is shown in the image below. Evaluation reveals homocystinuria. Intake of which of the following should be reduced in his diet?
questions.solution:
Methionine intake should be reduced in patients with homocystinuria.

Homocystinuria is an important cause of pediatric stroke. It is most commonly caused by a defect in cystathionine β synthase enzyme leading to the accumulation of homocysteine in urine and blood. They are generally normal at birth and the first sign is subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis) seen after 3 years of age.

Manifestations of homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioural disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic lab findings.

 

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia is suspected to have endometriosis. On what basis would this condition be staged?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is staged according to the American Society of Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) system based on the extent of the disease as directly visualised on surgery/laparoscopy.

According to the ASRM system, based on the intra-operative findings, endometriosis of the ovaries, fallopian tubes, cul-de-sac and peritoneum are scored according to the surface area involved, depth, morphology and adhesions, and endometriosis is staged as Stage I (minimal), Stage II (mild), Stage III (moderate) and Stage IV (severe). 

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrium at a site outside the uterine cavity. It can be found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Dysmenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom, associated with abdominal and pelvic pain, menorrhagia, dyspareunia and infertility. Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. Typical characteristics include 'powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis.

For minimal disease, medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonize estrogenic effects on the endometrium, causing endometrial atrophy are used.

Surgery is preferred in patients with infertility. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser, and resection of endometrioma can be done. Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of COPD presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening dyspnea, productive cough, and altered mental status. On examination, he is tachypneic, cyanotic, and has a reduced level of consciousness. He is also hypotensive and tachycardic. His arterial blood gas shows a significant acidosis with a pH of 7.20, a pCO2 of 80 mmHg, and a pO2 of 50 mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is intubation.

This patient is in severe respiratory distress with significant acidosis and hemodynamic instability. He is at high risk of respiratory failure and cardiac arrest. Intubation is the only option that will provide adequate oxygenation and ventilation and allow for the correction of the acidosis. (GCS < 8 -> Intub8)

NIPPV (non-invasive positive pressure ventilation) is, infact, contraindicated in patients with hemodynamic instability, altered mental status/reduced consciousnes/inability to cooperate, and an inability to clear secretions. Other contraindications include craniofacial deformities/abnormalities and fitting problems, i.e obesity, facial burns, etc. (Option A)

Systemic corticosteroids are useful in the treatment of acute exacerbations of COPD as they reduce airway inflammation and improve lung function over time. However, the effects are not immediate and they do not address his respiratory failure. (Options C, D)

In general, NIPPV should be the first mode of ventilation used in COPD patients with acute respiratory failure provided there are no absolute contraindications. This approach improves gas exchange, reduces work of breathing and the need for intubation, decreases hospitalization duration and enhances overall survival outcomes. Invasive positive pressure ventilation is usually considered after failure of NIPPV, resulting in severe respiratory distress, life threatening hypoxemia, severe hypercarbia and/or acidosis, markedly impaired mental status, respiratory arrest or hemodynamic instability.

Apart from NIPPV, short-acting inhaled beta 2 agonists (albuterol, salbutamol) with or without short-acting anticholinergics (ipratropium, tiotropium) are recommended as the initial bronchodilators. Maintenance therapy with long-acting beta 2 agonists (formoterol) must be started as soon as possible. Antibiotics can also be considered, as they reduce duration of hospitalisation. Treatment is given for 5 days. 

*An exacerbation of COPD is characterized by dyspnea and/or cough and sputum that worsen over < 14 days. Exacerbations of COPD are often associated with increased local and systemic inflammation caused by airway infection, pollution, or other insults to the lungs.

questions.text: A 5-week-old male baby was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of non-bilious vomiting after feeding. A mass could be palpated in the right upper quadrant. Ultrasound of the abdomen showed the thickening of the pylorus muscle. What is the immediate next step of management?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 5-week-old male infant presenting with non-bilious vomiting after feeding along with the palpation of a mass in the right upper quadrant is suggestive of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. The immediate next step in management is to correct the electrolyte imbalance.

The recurrent vomiting secondary to the gastric outlet obstruction leads to dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis. This abnormality has to be corrected and adequate rehydration ensured before the surgery is undertaken. Normal saline with 0.15% KCl in 5% dextrose is used for maintenance and correction of the deficit.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS), is an uncommon condition in infants characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. It is more commonly seen in first-born male infants. Infants usually present between 2-8 weeks of age with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is a progressive condition and can be distinguished from other causes of vomiting such as infections because the baby is particularly hungry. 

During the test feed, gastric peristalsis moving from left to right of the upper abdomen is visible, and in a relaxed baby, an olive-shaped mass can be palpated in the right upper quadrant.

IHPS can be diagnosed clinically and confirmed by an ultrasound. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign. Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple sign (given in the image below).

A radiograph may show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble). 

 

Surgery can be done once the electrolyte imbalance is corrected. Routine preoperative evaluation is conducted, oral feeding is discontinued and the stomach is emptied with a nasogastric tube. Intravenous fluids are given to replace the ongoing gastric losses.

The hypertrophic pylorus is corrected by Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy. Postoperatively, intravenous fluids are continued until oral feeding is established in 24 hours. This surgery is the definitive management of this condition and has no long-term sequelae.

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked in the X-ray?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given X-ray image is the renal pelvis. It is embryologically derived from intermediate mesoderm.

The urinary and reproductive organs are developed from the intermediate mesoderm. 

After the notochord is formed, the intraembryonic mesoderm on either side can be seen organized into 3 layers:

  • Paraxial mesoderm: A thickened plate of the mesoderm close to the midline, on either side of the notochord. This forms the somitomeres and somites.
  • Intermediate mesoderm: Longitudinal strip of mesoderm that connects paraxial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The urinary and genital systems are derived from the intermediate mesoderm.
  • Lateral plate mesoderm: A thinner layer of mesoderm that lies laterally. This layer develops a large cavity called the intraembryonic coelom that gives rise to pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts

Lateral plate mesoderm

  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum

questions.text: Which of the following indicates the site of placement of the tube shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kehr’s T-tube which is placed in the common bile duct after choledochotomy.

The horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct while the vertical limb is brought out like a drain.

It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

A T-tube should be left in place for a minimum of 2-3 weeks to promote the formation of a fistulous tract and reduce the possibility of biliary peritonitis following T-tube removal. Once the T-tube cholangiogram has shown that there is a free flow of bile into the duodenum and that there are no retained stones, it is removed. 

Other options:

Option B: Renal calyx- A nephrostomy tube is inserted into the renal calyx. During the procedure, a catheter is inserted through the skin into the renal calyx using image guidance. Drainage of an obstructed renal unit is the most common indication.

Option C: Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tubes used for enteral feeding and stomach decompression are inserted transabdominally into the stomach.

Option D: Caecum - A caecostomy tube is a small tube that extends from the skin’s surface to the caecum. It involves bridging the caecum through the abdominal wall and opening it for drainage or decompression. It is mainly used in the management of faecal incontinence in children.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs will be useful in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves, (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Out of the given drugs, Verapamil can be used in the treatment of PSVT.

PSVT is an arrhythmia characterized by sudden onset and offset with rapid ventricular response. It includes atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia, junctional tachycardia, and AV reentry tachycardia. Initial management of PSVT is by vagal maneuvers such as carotid massage. If this method is ineffective, intravenous adenosine is used which will terminate the majority of PSVT episodes by blocking the conduction at AV node. Beta-blockers and non-DHP calcium channel blockers like Verapamil and Diltiazem are also able to block AV nodal conduction and can therefore be used in patients with PSVT.

Verapamil is a class IV anti-arrhythmic agent. It is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It acts by slowing down the SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. This decreases the conduction velocity and prolongs the refractory period, leading to the effective termination of the re-entrant current. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure. Diltiazem acts in a similar manner. Side effects of Verapamil include hypotension, bradycardia, constipation, and rarely, worsening of heart failure.

Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like Nifedipine, Amlodipine, and Cilnidipine do not have any antiarrhythmic properties.

 

Other options:

Option A: Cilnidipine blocks both N and L-type calcium channels. It is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It blocks the L-type calcium channels in blood vessels and inhibits the contraction of blood vessels and blocks the N-type calcium channels located at the sympathetic nerve endings, inhibiting the release of norepinephrine. It is used in hypertension, especially in patients with diabetes who present with albuminuria and chronic kidney disease as it has end-organ protective properties.

Option B: Fenoldopam injection is a dopaminergic agonist. It is indicated in adult patients for short-term management of severe hypertension when rapid and reversible reduction of blood pressure is clinically indicated, including for hypertensive emergencies. 

Option D: Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine that acts by blocking L-type calcium channels, having a rapid onset and short duration of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia. Increased heart rate increases the O2 demand and might precipitate angina.

questions.text: As a surgery intern, you are asked to check for the presence of Blumer shelf nodules in a 55-year-old female patient, who is a known case of gastric cancer. Which of the following methods will you use?
questions.solution:
Blumer shelf nodules indicate metastatic tumour deposits in the pouch of Douglas/ retrovesical pouch, identified on per rectal examination. It is seen in cases of advanced gastric cancer. 

A complete history and physical examination should be performed in patients with gastric cancer, with special attention to any evidence of advanced disease. Heme-positive stool and hard nodularity extraluminally and anteriorly may be seen on a rectal examination, indicating Blumer shelf nodules. It can also be seen in advanced cases of pancreatic, colonic or lung malignancies.

It is one of the atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma. Other atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma include:

  • Virchow's node
    • Supraclavicular sentinel lymph node involvement 
  • Sister Mary Joseph's nodule
    • Due to periumbilical metastasis. 
    • See in both gastric cancer (most common) and ovarian cancer. 
  • Krukenberg’s tumour
    • Bilateral ovarian metastasis
    • Due to retrograde lymphatic spread
  • Irish nodule
    • Left axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Trousseau syndrome
    • Migratory thrombophlebitis
  • Leser Trelet sign
    • Multiple seborrheic keratoses
    • Resolves after gastrectomy
  • Tripe palms
    • Hyperkeratosis palm.

questions.text: Hemoglobin (Hb) levels were measured in 200 pregnant women and a mean value of 10.5 g/dL was obtained with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming a normal distribution, what is the percentage of the study population with Hb <10g/dL?
questions.solution:
16% of the study population would have a Hb <10 g/dL.

Assuming a normal distribution, if the mean is 10.5 g/dL, 68% of the study population would have an Hb between 10-11 g/dL, being within 1 standard deviation. 

This means that, of the remaining population of 32% (100-68=32) falling outside 1 standard deviation, half of them, i.e., ½ of 32% = 16%, would have a Hb <10 g/dL and 16% would have a Hb >11 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean

Other Options:

Option A: 32% of the population would represent all those falling outside 1 standard deviation of the mean value of 10.5, i.e., the group that has a Hb<10 g/dL and Hb>11 g/dL.

Option C: 68% of the population would represent all those falling within 1 standard deviation of the mean value of 10.5, i.e., the group that has a Hb>10 g/dL and Hb<11 g/dL.

Option D: 95% of the population would represent all those falling within 2 standard deviations of the mean value of 10.5, i.e., the group that has a Hb < 9.5 g/dL and Hb>10.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: All the following are steps of post-transcriptional modification of eukaryotic mRNA, except ______.
questions.solution:
Dephosphorylation does not take place during post-transcriptional modification.

After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications, including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly A tail, and splicing.

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre-mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backwards to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage that is resistant to nucleases.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. This helps stabilize the mRNA, facilitates its exit from the nucleus, and aids in translation. The poly-A tail terminates eukaryotic transcription.
  • Maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns and joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. This is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

questions.text:
Match the following surgical procedures with the corresponding conditions for which they are performed:
Procedure Condition

1. Ramstedt's procedure

A. Peyronie's disease

2. Nesbitt procedure

 B. Biliary atresia

3. Heller's operation

 C. Infantile-hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

4. Kasai procedure

 D. Achalasia cardia
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  1. Ramstedt's procedure - Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  2. Nesbitt procedure - Peyronie's disease
  3. Heller's operation - Achalasia cardia
  4. Kasai procedure - Biliary atresia

Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy is performed by a laparoscopic or open supraumbilical incision for the treatment of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Nesbitt procedure is the most commonly used procedure for treating Peyronie's disease. It corrects the deformity by plicating the convex side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Heller's Myotomy is done for achalasia cardia. It involves cutting the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia of the stomach. It is often combined with a partial anterior fundoplication (Heller-Dor procedure) to avoid the complication of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. In this procedure, radical excision of all bile duct tissues up to the liver capsule is performed. A Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text: Which of the following segments in the given image represents the 'incubation period'?
questions.solution:
In the given image, 3 represents the incubation period, which is defined as the time interval between the invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom or sign of the disease.

Other Options

Option A: 1 represents the latent period, which is the interval between the invasion by an infectious agent and the time from which the infected individual becomes infectious. 

Option B: 2 represents the infective period, which is the period from which the infected individual may transmit the organism to an uninfected individual. The infective period may begin before the appearance of the first clinical sign or symptom.

Option D: 4 represents the clinical period, which is the time during which an infected individual shows symptoms and signs of the disease.

questions.text: A sanitation worker comes with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia developed pigmentation on the nose(Chik sign) after a few days. Which of the following interventions could have prevented his disease?

choices.text: Avoiding training near open water sources
Use of insect repellants while outside

questions.solution:
The given history of fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia, and nose hyperpigmentation (chik sign) points towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. This condition is spread via the Aedes aegypti mosquito. As per the CDC, one of the methods of preventing mosquito-borne diseases is by using clothes treated with permethrin or using insect repellants safe for dermatological use, especially in individuals who have occupations that require them to stay outside for a long time.

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus, spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever, arthralgia, and myalgia with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the serum with ELISA or RTPCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

Prevention of chikungunya is mainly by avoiding mosquito bites. Some measures include:

  • Use of mosquito nets
  • Use of permethrin-treated clothes and boots. 
  • Use of insect repellants
  • Sleeping in areas that are closed to avoid mosquito infestations

Other options:

Option A- Avoiding of consumption of food that is undercooked or uncovered decreases the risk of transmission of various pathogens including bacteria, viruses, and worms. However, this patient's condition is spread by mosquitos and requires a different mode of control.

Option B: Avoiding work near open water sources is not feasible for a sanitation worker. Advise should be such that it should not affect his occupation. Option D is more easy to bring into practice. 

Option C: Not using boots makes hookworms like Ancylostoma duodenal more likely. However, the symptoms in the stem are pointing towards chikungunya, so a different method of prevention should be used first.

questions.text: A 39-year-old P2L2 female patient presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen with irregular menses over the past 2 months. An ultrasound is carried out which reveals an adnexal cystic lesion. Which of the following features might suggest that it is a neoplastic rather than a functional cyst?
questions.solution:
An ovarian cyst may need further investigation if it is >7cm in size as this could indicate a neoplastic growth. 

Physiological/functional cysts of the ovary include:

  • Follicular cyst - Failure of rupture of the follicle during ovulation.
  • Theca lutein cyst - Stimulation of atretic follicles by abnormal HCG levels. It regresses when hCG levels fall.
  • Luteoma of pregnancy - Due to prolonged elevation of hCG, like in multiple pregnancies.

Functional ovarian cysts are at least 3cm but not more than 7cm. Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously within 4-6 months. A lesion that is >7cm or not regressing beyond 3 months, should prompt further investigations.

Other features of a functional cyst include:

  • Related to temporary hormonal variation
  • Benign and rarely becomes complicated
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless hemorrhage occurs

questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the image is an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, which is seen in G-6-PD deficiency.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected and females are carriers.
  • No male-to-male transmission. Females transmit the disease.
  • Affected males have carrier daughters and unaffected sons.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

Other options:

Option A: Gaucher's disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder that arises due to the deficiency of β-glucosidase. It is characterized by hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, bone pain, and pathological fractures.

Option B: Galactosemia is an autosomal recessive condition due to the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This leads to the accumulation of galactose and subsequent tissue damage.

The following image depicts autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Option D: MELAS (mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) follows a mitochondrial inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is false about the management of her condition?

choices.text: Latzko procedure is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula, caused by cancer cervix
Following a failed attempt, a second attempt can be made after 4 weeks
Continous bladder drainage required for 14 days postoperatively
Sexual abstinence for 3 months is advised after the surgery

questions.solution:
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

Vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It occurs mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterized by constant dribbling of urine.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken. Most vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix (Option A). It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia. Fistula located at the vaginal vault, post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.
  • Chassar-Moir technique: Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 
  • Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case previous surgeries fail.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days (Option C) along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months after surgery (Option D). Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.
