questions.text: A patient comes with a rash as shown in the picture. An isolate from one of the lesions grows cultures which are oxidase-positive. What history is likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Use of a shared hot tub
Use of a new skin care product

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with a folliculitis-like rash with an oxidase positive isolate has most likely developed hot tub folliculitis caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It occurs due to the use of shared hot tubs and jacuzzis which aren't cleaned that often. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer. Breach in primary body defenses as in burns predisposes to Pseudomonas infection.

Clinical features - It is characterized by blue-green pus. It is notorious for being resistant to antimicrobials and antiseptics and hence is a frequent contaminant in hospital samples. Repeated isolation and associated clinical features should prompt the diagnosis of Pseudomonas.

Diagnosis - It grows well on most media and pigment production makes its identification easy. Species identification is made possible by biochemical tests - arginine hydrolysis and oxidase reaction. 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella ) are oxidase negative.

questions.solution:
The above image shows transitional epithelium, identified by the variations in the cell layers: The deepest cell layer is columnar, the middle is made of polyhedral cells and lastly the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped. Transitional epithelium lines the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra (not the membranous urethra).  

Transitional epithelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium.  

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.

  • Membranous urethra: Pseudostratified columnar
  • Penile/Spongy urethra: Proximally: Pseudostratified columnar, Distally: Stratified squamous

questions.text: Cushing's reflex following brain ischemia is associated with a decrease in -
questions.solution:
Cushing reflex is associated with a decrease in heart rate.

Cushing reaction occurs in response to the CNS ischemia due to an increase in CSF pressure around the brain.

When the CSF pressure increases beyond the arterial pressure, the cerebral arteries are compressed causing decreased blood flow to the brain. This causes an increase in CO2 and a decrease in pH, which stimulates the medullary chemoreceptors and thereby triggers the CNS ischemic response.

CNS ischemic response is characterized by increased sympathetic activity, decreased parasympathetic activity, and arteriolar vasoconstriction, increasing arterial pressure and total peripheral resistance. As a result, the arterial pressure rises higher than the CSF pressure, which restores the blood flow to the brain.

Despite an increase in sympathetic activity, bradycardia is seen, rather than tachycardia. This reflex bradycardia occurs due to the stimulation of arterial baroreceptors by raised blood pressure.

A 13-year-old girl with a scoliotic curve beginning at T10 should be provided with a Boston brace. It is the commonest brace prescribed for scoliosis and is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. The Boston brace works by applying corrective pressure on the convex side of the curve. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 

Boston brace is also available as a Cervical TLSO brace - which is a TLSO with a neck extension. It is used for the correction of a high thoracic curve.

Wilmington Brace is another common TLSO brace that is custom-fitted based on a cast taken of the patient in the supine position. The brace fits onto the body like a tight jacket, known as a full-contact TLSO. There are no gaps or open spots.

 

A 12-year-old girl with a single thoracolumbar scoliotic curve to wear while sleeping should be provided with a Charleston bending brace. It is the most commonly prescribed nighttime brace. It is custom-fitted based and is intended to be worn while lying down. It applies lateral force to the spine, pushing the curve closer to the midline and holds it in an overcorrected position. 

Providence Brace is similar to the Charleston brace. It applies a hypercorrective force on the spine while lying down. It slightly elevates one shoulder and directly applies lateral and rotational forces on the curve (or both curves if it is a double curve).

 

A 40-year-old recovering from Dorso-lumbar surgery should be provided with an ASHE brace (anterior spinal hyperextension brace).  A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. 

A 20-year-old man with a cervical spine injury should be treated with a SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace. It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

Other options: 

Milwaukee brace is the originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) introduced in the 1940s. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is brought by his wife who reports episodes of punching and kicking in his sleep for the past month. The patient is unaware of this and only recalls vivid dreams during these episodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with episodes of punching and kicking during sleep and recall of vivid dreams is likely suffering from REM sleep behaviour disorder.

REM (rapid eye movement) sleep behaviour disorder (RBD) involves failure of atonia (sleep paralysis) during the REM stage sleep resulting in dream enactment such as punching, kicking, leaping, and running from bed. REM sleep behavior disorder is associated with vivid dream imagery, and individuals with this condition seem to be unaware of their actual surroundings, unlike sleepwalking.

Patients and bed partners frequently sustain injuries. RBD may result from diffuse hemispheric lesions, lewy body dementia, bilateral thalamic abnormalities, or brainstem lesions. Clonazepam can treat RBD.

Other options :

Option A: Somnambulism (sleep walking) occurs during NREM sleep and is more common in children. It is characterized by repeated episodes of rising from bed during sleep and walking about. While sleepwalking, the individual has a blank, staring face, is relatively unresponsive to the efforts of others to communicate with him or her, and can be awakened only with great difficulty.

Option C: Restless leg syndrome is characterized by an unpleasant creeping-crawling sensation in the legs accompanied by an irresistible urge to move them, typically when at rest or trying to fall asleep. This can lead to significant sleep disturbances and insomnia.

Option D : Pavor nocturnus (night terrors) are sleep arousal disorders that are seen in NREM sleep. The disorder is mostly seen in young children and rarely in adults. Clinical features include intense fear, characterised by screaming and relative unresponsiveness to the efforts of others to comfort the patient and no memory of the episode.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored.  His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following has no role in his management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Propranolol is a beta blocker used in the management of hypertension, but it has no known benefits in the management of CRAO.

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk factors include:

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma

Etiology:

  • Emboli - emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are - cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Clinical features are:

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Amaurosis fugax - transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia. As seen in this patient.
  • Direct pupillary reflex is absent
  • Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is positive

Fundus examination shows:

  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance
  • Cherry red spot
  • Severe edema 
  • Retinal pallor

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: The amino acid deficient in carcinoid syndrome has which of the following groups?
questions.solution:
The amino acid deficient in carcinoid syndrome is tryptophan. It has an indole group.

Carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours producing serotonin. Serotonin is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. Carcinoid patients can have tryptophan deficiency as the normal intake of niacin and tryptophan don’t meet the demand from the cancer cells. Tryptophan has an indole group.

Tryptophan deficiency results in pellagra.

questions.text: A mother brings her daugher for counselling for LASIK surgery. Which of the following conditions is an absolute contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Keratoconus is an absolute contraindication to LASIK. Any patient being considered for a LASIK surgery should be screened for the presence of keratoconus.

Myopia also known as shortsightedness is a refractive error in which parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of the retina with the accommodation at rest. 

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the commonly done surgery for myopia. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has been brought to the physician following a drop in school performance, personality changes, and behavioral difficulties. After thorough investigations, he is diagnosed with metachromatic leukodystrophy. The accumulation of which of the following lipids is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The accumulation of sulfogalactocerebroside is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy. 

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. It is a serious condition and causes death within 5-6 years in early-onset form.

Clinical manifestations of the diseases can be categorized by the age of disease onset:

Late infantile-onset: Occurs in children < 30 months of age. Typically, early milestones are met, followed by a progressive regression of motor skills, ataxia, dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, extensor plantar posturing, and optic atrophy. Accounts for a majority of the cases.
 
Juvenile onset: Occurs between 30 months and puberty. Early milestones are met, followed by psychomotor regression, intellectual decline in the form of dropped school performance, behavioral difficulties, and personality changes.
 
Adult-onset: This type shows neurocognitive and neuropsychiatric difficulties. Patients may have dysesthesias like peripheral neuropathy, psychosis, schizophrenia, or seizures. 

Other options

Option A: Galactosylceramide accumulation occurs in Krabbe’s leukodystrophy.

Option C: Sphingomyelin accumulation occurs in Neimann-Pick disease

Option D: Globoside accumulation occurs in Sandhoff's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of aphakia?
questions.solution:
The anterior chamber is deeper in aphakia.

Signs of surgical aphakia include the following:

  • Limbal scar
  • Anterior chamber deeper than normal
  • Iridodonesis (tremulousness of the iris)
  • Jet black color of the pupil
  • Only the first and second images (normally, four images are seen) seen on Purkinje’s image test
  • Small disc seen on fundus examination
  • High hypermetropia seen on retinoscopy

Treatment:

Secondary intraocular lens (IOL) implantation is the best option.

questions.text: An 8-month-old male infant is found to have bilateral renal masses. The infant had an omphalocele, macroglossia and macrosomia at birth. Which of the following is the genetic basis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This infant presenting with bilateral renal masses, and history of omphalocele, macroglossia, and macrosomia at birth most likely has Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which occurs due to genomic imprinting.

Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome is characterized by neonatal hypoglycemia, macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia. omphalocele, visceromegaly and embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is the WT2 locus in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) distal to the WT1 locus. This region contains multiple genes that are normally expressed from only one of the two parental alleles, with silencing (imprinting) of the other. IGF2 gene abnormalities have the strongest correlation to the development of tumors. Loss of maternal imprinting of IGF2 and uniparental paternal disomy of IGF2 are 2 pathways that can cause overexpression of IGF2 thus leading to tumorigenesis.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

Other options: 

Option A: Mosaicism is the phenomenon where a single organism possesses more than one genetic line as the result of genetic mutation.

Option B: Anticipation is the phenomenon where symptoms become more severe and/or appear at an earlier age as the disorder is passed from one generation to the next.

Option D: De novo mutation such as germline deletions of 11p13 is associated with WAGR syndrome. In Denys-Drash syndrome the genetic abnormality is a dominant-negative missense mutation in the zinc-finger region of the WT1 protein that affects its DNA-binding properties.

questions.text: Which of the following tubes is ideally used for performing gastric lavage in patients with suspected poisoning?
questions.solution:
The tube used for performing gastric lavage is the Ewald tube. It is also known as Boa tube, stomach tube, or orogastric lavage tube.

Gastric lavage is the administration and evacuation of small volumes of liquid through an orogastric tube to remove toxic substances within the stomach. In adults, small amounts of warm water or saline are administered and, via a siphoning action, removed again. In children, normal saline is used because children are at greater risk of developing hyponatremia if lavaged with water.

In an unconscious patient, gastric lavage is performed after induction of general anesthesia with the patient intubated, to prevent aspiration.

Ryle tube (nasogastric tube) is indicated in intestinal obstruction and nutritional support. It is also used for gastric lavage but is preferred more in children.

Sengstaken Blakemore tube is used for balloon tamponade in case of hemorrhage due to esophageal varices. 

Salem Sump tube is used for gastrointestinal decompression. It has 2 lumens.

questions.text: A patient with 50% burns of the body surface area is started on antibiotics, IV fluids, NSAIDs and opioids, and wound care. 2 days later, she develops abdominal pain and vomiting. Endoscopy reveals multiple shallow erosions in the stomach and duodenum.  What ulcers are these?
questions.solution:
This patients clinical features are suggestive of Curlings ulcers. Curling ulcers are associated with severe burns or trauma. Curling ulcers occur as multiple shallow erosions in the stomach and proximal duodenum.

Systemic hypotension or reduced blood flow caused by stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction results in gastric mucosal injury. Mucosal ischemia, breakdown of the normal protective barriers of the stomach, systemic release of cytokines, poor GI motility, and oxidative stress also important role in the pathogenesis. Curling ulcers are most commonly observed in the acid-producing - fundus and body - of the stomach.
The most common presentation is GI bleeding, which is usually minimal but can occasionally be life threatening.

Other options:

Option A: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastric acid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

Option C: Martorell’s ulcers are seen in patients with prolonged/suboptimal controlled hypertension.

Option D: Marjolin's ulcers reflect malignant degeneration arising within a pre-existing cicatrix or scar and can transform into squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of a chemical synapse?
questions.solution:
Synaptic delay is seen in chemical synapses, but not in electrical synapses.

The minimum time for transmission across one synapse is 0.5 ms, it is possible to determine whether a given reflex pathway is monosynaptic or polysynaptic (contains more than one synapse) by measuring the synaptic delay.

Other Options:

Options B, C, D: Are features of electrical synapses.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with cyanosis and dyspnea despite being on high-flow oxygen therapy after using EMLA cream for pain. An ABG reveals a pH of 7.45, pO2 of 100 mmHg, pCO2 of 35 mmHg, and HCO3- of 24 mEq/L. What is the best method of determining oxygen saturation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Co-oximetry is the most accurate method of determining oxygen saturation in patients with methemoglobinemia. It is a spectrophotometer that can measure the relative absorbance of 4 different wavelengths of light, which allows it to differentiate between methemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, deoxyhemoglobin, and carboxyhemoglobin. 

This patient likely has methemoglobinemia, as suggested by lack of improvement with oxygen following a history of EMLA cream usage. EMLA is a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics containing a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. Methemoglobinemia is a serious side effect of the application of large amounts of prilocaine. Prilocaine is metabolized to O-toluidine, which converts hemoglobin (Fe2+) to methemoglobin (Fe3+) producing methemoglobinemia. This side effect is dose-dependent. 

Treatment of methemoglobinemia associated with isosorbide toxicity involves supportive care, cessation of offending agent, and reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Pulse oximetry is inaccurate in the setting of methemoglobinemia because it cannot distinguish methemoglobin from oxyhemoglobin. (Option A) Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and irrespective of the methemoglobin levels

Arterial blood gas analysis is a more invasive method of measuring oxygen saturation; It is more accurate than pulse oximetry, but less accurate than co-oximetry. Capillary blood gas analysis is even less accurate than arterial blood gas analysis in the setting of methemoglobinemia. (Options C, D)

questions.text: A patient was prescribed bleomycin as part of his chemotherapy regimen. At which stage of the cell cycle does the drug act?
questions.solution:
Bleomycin is a cytotoxic antibiotic that exerts its antitumor effect by causing DNA damage. It is a cell cycle specific drug that acts during the G2 phase of the cell cycle, just before mitosis.  

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer, testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. Its mechanism of action involves binding to iron ions and generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) that damage DNA by causing single- and double-strand breaks. 

Bleomycin has a little myelosuppression effect. The major adverse events include dose-dependent pulmonary toxicity (irreversible pulmonary fibrosis) and flagellate dermatitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Cells in the G0 phase are in a resting state and haven't initiated DNA replication. Cell cycle non specific drugs can act during this phase.

Option B: Cells in the S phase are actively replicating their DNA. Antimetabolites such as methotrexate, gemcitabine, cladribine, etc. act during this phase.

Option D: Cells in the M phase are undergoing mitosis. Drugs such as microtubule inhibitors (paclitaxel, vincristine, vinblastine) act during this phase.

questions.text: A feedback survey was conducted in a clinic and 10 patients with the following ages responded: 24, 36, 37, 45, 46, 24, 30, 50, 33, 20. Calculate the range of this data.
questions.solution:
From the given ages of participants, the lowest age is 20 years and the highest age is 50 years, hence the range is 50 - 20 = 30.

Range gives the difference between the highest and lowest values in a given set of data.

If the data is arranged in ascending order (20, 24, 24, 30, 33, 36, 37, 45, 46, 50), it would be easier to calculate other parameters such as:

  • Mean would be the sum of all, divided by the number of participants, ie, 345/10 = 34.5
  • Median, in this case with even number of values, would be the average of the middle values, ie, (33+36)/2 = 34.5
  • Mode, the most frequently occurring variable, would be 24.

  • The disadvantage of the range is that it is sensitive to extreme values.

questions.text: In a research study, a total of 200 mCi of Deuterium Oxide (D2O) is injected into the venous blood of a volunteer. During a 2 hour equilibration period, he excretes 25% of the injected deuterium oxide. If plasma concentration of D2O is subsequently measured to be 0.333mCi/100 ml, calculate the total body water in this volunteer.
questions.solution:
The Total Body Water (TBW) in this volunteer would be 45L.

The volume of each of the body fluid compartments can be measured by the dilution method. By this method, the volume of the TBW in this patient is calculated by the formula:

Where,
  • V = TBW volume in liters (L)
  • Amount of deuterium oxide (marker) injected = 200 mCi
  • Amount of deuterium oxide excreted = 25% of 200 mCi = 50 mCi
  • Plasma concentration of deuterium oxide = 0.333 mCi/100mL = 3.33 mCi/L 

By substituting the given values, the volume of total body water is calculated as:

TBW Volume = (200 - 50)/3.3

                   = 45 liters

Therefore, the total body water in this volunteer would be 45 litres.

Isotopic water like deuterium oxide (D2O) would be distributed everywhere that water is found in the body due on account of its lipid solubility. Therefore, it can be used as an appropriate marker substance for the calculation of total body water. Other markers for total body water include tritiated water (THO) and antipyrine.

Estimation of total body water is of clinical importance due to its direct correlation with important parameters like a person's body weight. Water accounts for about 50-70% of the total body weight and in the absence of other comorbidities, the magnitude of weight loss is directly proportional to the amount of total body water that is lost.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is taking hormone replacement therapy for menopause and has hypothyroidism which had been well maintained on a levothyroxine supplement of 200 micrograms. She comes to the clinic for a routine check-up and her TSH level is found to be elevated. What is the most likely reason for her elevated TSH level?
questions.solution:
Hormone replacement therapy can increase TBG concentration -> which binds to thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), making them less available -> leading to an elevated TSH level, even if the patient is taking an adequate dose of levothyroxine.

Estrogens raise the circulating levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), thereby increasing the bound fraction and decreasing the free (bioactive) fraction of circulating thyroxine (T4). As a consequence, estrogen therapy increases the T4 supplementation requirements of women being treated for primary hypothyroidism.

Drugs increasing TBG levels: 

  • Estrogens
  • Tamoxifen
  • Methadone
  • 5-fluorouracil  

Drugs decreasing TBG levels: 

  • Androgens
  • Corticosteroids
  • Niacin

Drugs decreasing binding of T4 to TBG (by displacement):

  • Salicylates (aspirin, mefenamic acid)
  • Heparin
  • Furosemide

Option A: Decreased levothyroxine absorption is caused by bile acid binders, iron/calcium/aluminium supplementation and proton pump inhibitors that bind to and inhibit the absorpiton thyroxine.

Option C: Increased levothyroxine metabolism can occur via icreased glucuronidation/sulfation/deiodination by CYP450 inducers/inhibitors such as rifampin, phenytoin, carbamazepine, etc.

Option D: Euthyroid sick syndrome is a condition that can cause an elevated TSH level, but it is usually associated with non-thyroidal illnesses, such as infection or major surgery. The patient in this case does not have any obvious non-thyroidal illnesses.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented with pain and swelling in her knee. Histopathology of the lesion showed a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells seen scattered amidst round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The stroma appeared well vascularized, with bands of fibrous tissue with areas of hemorrhage and collections of foamy macrophages interspersed in between. Which of the following x-rays belongs to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem and characteristic histopathology findings are suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT), or osteoclastoma. The x-ray findings of GCT are seen in Image 2, which shows an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular lesion, with a soap-bubble appearance.

A GCT is typically seen on x-ray as an eccentric, lobulated, lytic lesion with non-sclerotic borders, giving a soap-bubble appearance. GCTs usually have little or no matrix calcification, new bone formation, or periosteal reaction. Tumors that extend into the soft tissues are seen as soft-tissue masses, which may be covered by a thin layer of sclerosis. They are usually located in the epiphysis of the long bone, but may also extend to the metaphysis. If malignant, the tumor appears as a lytic lesion with a sclerosing destructive tumor adjacent to it.

CT imaging estimates cortical bone involvement, and MRI shows an isointense or hypointense lesion on T1-weighted images.

GCTs are benign but locally aggressive tumors of the bone and are characterized by a proliferation of mononuclear cells, with scattered macrophages. They are most commonly seen at 20–45 years of age. GCTs may occasionally be associated with Paget’s disease of bone and focal dermal hypoplasia (Goltz syndrome).

They are seen in the epiphysis of long bones, more commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus. Patients present with pain and a mass. 

Histologically, GCTs consist of a large number of osteoclast-like giant cells, with scattered, round, or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized, with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. Interposed areas of hemorrhage, hemosiderin, and foamy macrophages are seen.

The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

Other options:

Image 1: It shows Brodie's abscess, which is a small cavity in the bone with little or no periosteal reaction, seen in subacute osteomyelitis.

Image 3: It shows multiple osteochondromas around the knee joint. An osteochondroma is a common benign, cartilaginous neoplasm, seen more often in males during adolescent years. Pedunculated osteochondromas typically point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis.

Image 4: It shows osteosarcoma with a sunburst appearance. They appear as ill-defined, bone-forming lesions causing cortical destruction, periosteal reaction, and expansion into the soft tissues. Codman’s triangle may be visualized where new bone forms in response to periosteal elevation.

questions.text: Which part of the vertebral artery traverses the foramen transversarium?
questions.solution:
The second part of the vertebral artery passes through the foramen transversarium in the transverse processes of all of the cervical vertebrae (except the seventh vertebra) and enters the cranium through the foramen magnum

The vertebral artery arises from the first part of the subclavian artery. It passes through the foramina of transverse processes of C6 to C1 cervical vertebrae and enters the cranium through the foramen magnum. The vertebral arteries of both sides join to form the basilar artery. In its course, it is divided into four parts:

The first part, V1, begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side. 

The second part, V2 is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae till C2. 

The third part, V3 is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle. 

The fourth part, V4 pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons.

questions.text:
You are managing a case of chronic pancreatitis. Which of the following dietary supplements would you not prescribe for a patient initially?
  1. Tocopherol
  2. Retinol
  3. Biotin
  4. Hydroxocobalamin
  5. Phytonadione
questions.solution:
A patient with chronic pancreatitis usually has difficulty digesting fats due to the deficiency of pancreatic lipases. So they usually require additional fat-soluble vitamin supplementation usually given IV or IM. Water-soluble vitamins (Biotin, Hydroxycobalamin) are usually given only if there is an overt deficiency. They aren't prescribed in the initial management of these patients. 

The water-soluble vitamins are the Vitamin B complex and Vitamin C. These are absorbed from the small intestine via carriers or by active transport, unlike the fat-soluble vitamins( Vitamins A, D, E, K) which require normal fat metabolism to be absorbed. Hence in conditions like chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis with deficient fat metabolism, patients require additional supplementation only for fat-soluble vitamins.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presenting with poor growth, hepatomegaly, and frequent hypoglycemia is diagnosed with Von-Gierke's disease. All of the following should be avoided in the diet except for which one?
questions.solution:
Patients with Von-Gierke's disease are given uncooked cornstarch as part of dietary therapy and should avoid foods containing fructose and galactose such as cane sugar, fruits and dairy products.

Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I) or Von Gierke’s disease occurs due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose 6 phosphatase. It is the most common of the glycogen storage diseases. Clinical manifestations result, directly or indirectly, from inability to maintain an adequate blood glucose level, glycogen accumulation in organs, excessive lactic acid generation, and hyperuricemia.

Clinical features include seizures, doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities), hepatomegaly, enlarged kidney and growth retardation.

Findings on lab tests include hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL), hyperuricemia (>5 mg/dL), lactic acidosis, hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia and neutropenia.

Treatment of von Gierke includes maintenance of glucose levels by nasogastric infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch. 

Since fructose and galactose should be restricted in the diet as they cannot be converted directly to glucose. Sucrose (table sugar, cane sugar, other ingredients), fructose (fruit, juice, high-fructose corn syrup), lactose (dairy foods), and sorbitol should be avoided or limited. Dietary restrictions can lead to deficiency of vitamins and minerals which may need to be supplemented.

HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors and fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy. Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

questions.text: The given instrument is designed to measure ______.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a dry and wet hygrometer and is designed to measure humidity. 

It consists of 2 similar thermometers beside each other. The dry bulb thermometer measures the dry bulb air temperature, and the wet bulb thermometer is kept moist with a wet muslin cloth covered over it. When both the temperature readings are equal, it signifies there is 100% saturation of the atmosphere with moisture. After obtaining both the readings, the relative humidity is calculated using psychrometric charts.

Other options:

Option A - Air velocity is calculated using anemometers. It consists of 4 hemispherical cups, attached to 2 crossed metal arms. The velocity of the wind is indicated on a counter called a cyclometer, placed on the anemometer. Kata thermometers are used as anemometers for low air velocities. 

Option C - Air pressure/Atmospheric pressure is measured using barometers.

Option D -  Air Quality Index (AQI) is complex air quality data of various pollutants that are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location. 

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a painful, slow and gradual enlargement at the insertion of the Achilles tendon. It gets relieved with rest.  On examination, the following finding is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and patient image point towards the diagnosis of Haglund deformity. 

Haglund deformity refers to a large exostosis at the posterosuperior aspect of the calcaneal tuberosity located anterior to the Achilles tendon. 

This pre-tendinous bursitis usually is caused by chronic irritation from a shoe heel counter. Modification of shoe wear usually relieves symptoms. 

Treatment includes mainly conservative management. Surgical treatment is indicated if conservative management fails.

 

Option A) Hallux valgus (shown below) is caused due to the excessive lateral deviation of the great toe with the prominence of the head of the first metatarsal. It can be congenital or a consequence of rheumatoid arthritis or excessive usage of footwear with narrow toe space. The commonest complaints are pain over the bunion, worries about cosmesis and difficulty fitting shoes. Often there is also deformity of the lesser toes and pain in the forefoot. 

 

Option B: In plantar fasciitis, there is pain and tenderness in the sole of the foot, mostly under the heel, with standing or walking. The condition progresses gradually, without any clear incident or injury, but sometimes there is a history of sudden increase in sporting activity, or a change of footwear, sports shoes or running surface. There may be an associated tightness of the Achilles tendon. 

Option D: Tarsal coalition usually occurs in older children and teenagers where they present with a painful, rigid flat foot in which the peroneal and extensor tendons are in spasm.

questions.text: A psychiatrist is conducting the Folstein test as a part of the psychiatric evaluation of a patient. Which of the following is being evaluated?
questions.solution:
The Folstein test also known as the mini-mental state examination (MMSE) is used to test cognitive functioning.

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes for completion. A score of less than 24 points to cognitive impairment.

It can be used to screen for and assess dementia. Some other screening tools are the Montreal cognitive assessment (MOCA), the tablet-based cognitive assessment tool, and cognistat.

The picture below shows a sample of the MMSE form:

Other options:

Option A: Tests and scales used for the rating and diagnosis of anxiety:

  • Panic disorder severity scale (PDSS)

Option B: Scales used for diagnosis and assessment of depression:

  • Hamilton rating scale for depression (HAM-D)
  • Beck depression inventory (BDI)

Option C: Tests used to measure intelligence quotient:

    • Wechsler intelligence scale for children (WISC-III-R)
    • Stanford-Binet intelligence scale (For ages 2 to 24 years)
  • Adults:
    • Wechsler adult intelligence scale (WAIS-111)

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain and breathlessness after a road traffic accident. No penetrating injury to the chest is seen. His chest X-ray is as given below. Which of the following is an indication for thoracotomy?

choices.text: Persistence of hemothorax despite a tube thoracostomy
Continuous bleeding < 50 ml/h for 3 consecutive hours
Drainage of > 1500 ml blood when chest tube is first inserted

questions.solution:
Drainage of >1500 ml blood when the chest tube is first inserted is an indication for thoracotomy.

The above clinical scenario with the chest radiograph showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification of the half of the hemithorax is suggestive of hemothorax. 

Thoracotomy is a creation of access to contents of the thoracic cavity by an incision between the ribs.

The indications for thoracotomy in a thoracic trauma are:

  • Drainage of more than 1500 ml (blunt trauma) or 1000ml (penetrating trauma) blood when the chest tube is first inserted
  • Continuous hemorrhage of more than 200 mL/h for 3 consecutive hours (Option C)
  • Caked hemothorax (Persistence of hemothorax despite two tube thoracotomies) (Option B)
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Inadequate ventilation with a massive air leak in chest tube
  • Trachea or main stem bronchial injury(diagnosed on imaging or endoscopy)
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Esophageal perforation
  • Air embolism

Other options:

Option A- Surgical emphysema is a common phenomenon complication tube thoracostomy for pneumothorax. It is usually benign, self-limiting that requires only conservative treatment.

questions.text: Ethmoidal bullectomy would entail the removal of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the osteomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and the same is removed in ethmoidal bullectomy.

This step should be performed carefully so as to avoid damage to the medial orbital wall, skull base, or anterior ethmoidal artery.

The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy. Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to approach the middle meatus.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

The following image gives an explanation of these structures.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis, refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of fronto-ethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

questions.text: What is the most commonly involved valve in case of carcinoid syndrome affecting the heart?
questions.solution:
The most commonly involved value in carcinoid syndrome is the tricuspid valve.

The right heart is more commonly affected than the left heart, with tricuspid involvement in more than 97% of patients. This is likely due to the effects of bradykinin and serotonin coming in contact with the tricuspid valve first. The pulmonary capillary bed degrades the metabolites and serves as a filter, relatively protecting the left side of the heart from fibrosis. (Options B, C, D)

Carcinoid heart disease is characterized by the formation of fibrous plaques on the heart valves, chambers, and blood vessels. These plaques can distort the valves, leading to stenosis or regurgitation. Patients with obvious carcinoid symptoms, such as flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm, are more likely to have cardiac involvement. Physical examination may reveal a murmur and signs of right heart failure. 

The carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum. a tumour with metastasis to the liver is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. 

The diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumours only if metastases are present.  

Ultrasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumour and metastases. The best method for staging carcinoid tumours is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).

Treatment:

Somatostatin and its analogues are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome. 
Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases.

The most common small intestine tumour is carcinoid.
The most common site of small intestine carcinoid is the ileum.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A child with cystic fibrosis underwent mutation analysis and was recommended a medication that helps increase chloride channel opening. Which of the following drugs is most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ivacaftor is a drug used in patients with cystic fibrosis that acts by increasing opening of chloride channels.

Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) modulator therapies are a new class of medications that correct the dysfunction by improving production, intracellular processing, or function of the CFTR protein. Ivacaftor is used for patients who harbor the G551D mutation. Ivacaftor, which is called a potentiator, acts by opening the mutant chloride channel, restoring the proper function of the protein.

Other agents such as lumacaftor, tezacaftor and elexacaftor are called correctors, that transport mutant CFTR proteins into the plasma membrane. Lumacaftor is found to be effective in patients with delta F508 mutations. Clinical benefit is seen when potentiators and correctors are given in combination. Correctors have no benefit clinically when given alone.

Other aspects of treatment in cystic fibrosis includes chest physiotherapy, postural drainage, short-term antibiotics, and inhaled bronchodilators. Inhaled hypertonic saline helps in mucus clearance. Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy can be done in case of pancreatic insufficiency. Lung transplant is the definitive treatment.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7q. It functions as an epithelial anion channel. It plays an important role in mucociliary transport along the respiratory mucosa. It also helps regulate the amount of exocrine gland secretion.

The defect in the ion channel results in the production of hyper-viscous, adherent secretions which can obstruct the airways. Organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus can grow in the sputum. The exocrine pancreas can undergo fibrotic scarring, cyst formation, and acinar tissue loss leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The viscid secretions can lead to pancreatic duct obstruction. The flow of digestive enzymes to the duodenum is hence impaired.

Symptoms include sinusitis, steatorrhea, and abdominal pain. Distal intestinal obstruction is a complication due to difficulty in excreting intestinal contents. In neonates, it can present as meconium ileus. Detection of high levels of immunogenic trypsinogen is used in newborn screening. Chloride level >60mEq/L in the sweat of affected patients is diagnostic. Hyponatremic hypochloremic alkalosis and hypokalemia may also be seen.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt trauma to his abdomen while playing sports. CT scan showed retroperitoneal hematoma. Trauma to which zone of retroperitoneum should always be explored surgically?
questions.solution:
Zone 1 injury should always be treated surgically.

Retroperitoneum is divided into 3 zones, based on the types of viscera and their differential management in blunt trauma.

The image given below shows the different zones of the retroperitoneum.

Zone 1 Central Always explored, after proximo-distal vascular control
Zone 2 Lateral Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization
Zone 3 Pelvic Only explored if the hematoma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembolization

If there is a penetrative injury in any of the zones, surgical management is done.

Mattox maneuver is left medial visceral rotation to expose the aorta. The Cattell-Braasch maneuver is done by right medial visceral rotation to expose the inferior vena cava.

questions.text: Which of the following patients most likely has Crohn's disease?

choices.text: A 45 year old smoker with colonoscopy showing two skip lesions in terminal ileum and caecum with cobblestone appearance
A 56 year old female with endoscopy showing multiple ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum
A 60 year old male with  colonoscopy showing a continuous lesion of the rectum and distal colon and collar button ulcers
A 23 year old female with pain, diarrhoea and constipation and normal findings on colonoscopy

questions.solution:
Of the given patients, the 45-year-old smoker with colonoscopy showing skip lesions in terminal ileum and caecum, with cobblestone appearance is most likely to have Crohn's disease.

Crohn disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It also has to skip lesions (as in this case: two lesions) and is associated with smoking.

Other options:

Option B: This patient may have Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterised by overproduction of gastrin from a tumour and multiple ulcers in atypical areas. 

Option C: This patient probably has ulcerative colitis, characterized by a continuous lesion with rectal involvement. 

Option D: This patient most likely has irritable bowel syndrome.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male patient presented with a history of progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past 2 years. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve on exercise. An x-ray image of his spine was taken and is given below. Which of the following characteristic findings seen from the image help in clinching the diagnosis?

1. Dagger spine appearance

2. Bullet-shaped vertebra

3. Trolley-track appearance

4. Squaring of the vertebral body

5. Rugger jersey spine
questions.solution:
A young male adult presenting with a history of lower backache and early morning stiffness, relieved upon exercising is suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. A radiograph of the spine shows a dagger spine, trolley-track appearance, and squaring of the vertebral body, which aid in confirming the diagnosis. 

The dagger sign is noted as a linear increased density running along with the spinous processes due to ossification of the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments. In addition, there are two more lateral vertical linear lines, which represent the ossification of paraspinous ligaments, resulting in a rail-road track sign. The three vertical ossified lines together make up the trolley-track sign.

Important radiological features of ankylosing spondylitis: 

  • Cardinal sign/ earliest sign on x-ray is the erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints.
  • Periarticular sclerosis and bony ankylosis of the joint can be seen.
  • The involvement of these joints is usually bilateral and symmetrical. 
  • Early detection by MRI pelvis shows subchondral bone marrow edema. 

CT image shows spine ankylosis continuously involving all the thoracolumbar vertebral bodies:

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the difference between quarantine and isolation?

choices.text: Quanrantine applies only to infected individuals
Quarantine applies to healthy contacts of infected cases
Isolation applies to healthy contacts of infected cases
Isolation does not apply to domestic animals

questions.solution:
Quarantine is defined as the limitation of freedom of movement of well-persons or animals, exposed to a communicable disease for a period of time not longer than the longest usual incubation period, to prevent contact with those not exposed.

In contrast, isolation is defined as the separation of infected persons or animal, for the period of communicability of the infection, to prevent direct or indirect transmission of the infection to those susceptible.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient consults a gynaecologist about hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) for her recent hot flushes. In which of the following  situations would it not be necessary to include progesterone in the HRT regimen for the patient?

choices.text: The patient has previously undergone a hysterectomy
The patient does not have associated vaginal atrophy
The patient has no family history of endometrial carcinoma
The patient has a history of uterine fibroids

questions.solution:
Progesterone is added to the HRT regimen to prevent endometrial hyperplasia and risk of carcinoma from unopposed estrogen, and is therefore not required in patients who have undergone a hysterectomy.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is indicated for the treatment of vasomotor symptoms such as hot flushes, osteoporosis (prevention and treatment), vaginal atrophy, urethral syndrome and dyspareunia. These symptoms occur primarily due to the deficiency of estrogen, which is the key hormone to be replaced. A short-term therapy of 3-6 months is usually recommended, and a long-term regimen for women with osteoporosis. Estrogen may be given in various formulations such as oral, transdermal, topical gel, or intravaginal creams. For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women who have previously undergone a hysterectomy, estrogen therapy alone is sufficient.

Indications for HRT:

  • Therapeutic:
    • Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency- vasomotor symptoms, vaginal atrophy (Option B)
    • Gonadal dysgenesis in adolescents
  • Prophylactic:
    • High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
    • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy 

Contraindications for HRT:

  • History of breast cancer or uterine cancer or family history of cancer (Option C)
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gallbladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids (Option D)—the fibroids may enlarge in size

questions.text: Which of the following causative organisms of neonatal sepsis can be acquired through the transplacental route?
questions.solution:
Among the causative organisms given that can cause neonatal sepsis, Listeria is the only one that can be transmitted through the transplacental route.

Transplacental infection of the fetus is common in neonatal listeriosis. Neonatal sepsis is a clinical syndrome characterized by signs and symptoms of infection, with or without accompanying bacteremia in the first month of life. Neonates present with either nonspecific manifestations or focal signs of infection, such as irritability, lethargy, seizures, feeding intolerance, temperature instability, hypotension, poor perfusion (pallor, mottled skin), metabolic acidosis, tachycardia or bradycardia, apnea, respiratory distress, grunting, cyanosis, abdominal distention, and jaundice.

All neonates suspected to have sepsis should have a septic screen to corroborate the diagnosis. The various components of the septic screen include:

  • Total leukocyte count (TLC)
  • Absolute neutrophil count (ANC)
  • Immature: Total neutrophil ratio (IT)
  • Micro-erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • C-reactive protein

Blood culture is the gold standard for diagnosis.

Early-onset sepsis is the onset of symptoms within 72 hours of age and usually manifests as respiratory distress or pneumonia. Early-onset infections are acquired before or during delivery (vertical mother-to-child transmission). 

Late-onset sepsis is generally defined as the onset of symptoms after 72 hours of age. Late-onset infections develop after delivery from organisms acquired in the hospital or the community.

  Early-onset sepsis Late-onset sepsis
Presentation Within the first 72 hours of life After 72 hours of life
Source of infection Maternal genital tract Nosocomial or community-acquired
Manifestation Respiratory distress and pneumonia Septicemia, pneumonia, or meningitis


Other options : 

Chlamydia, Group B Streptococci and Klebsiella are important causes of neonatal sepsis and are acquired in the perinatal or postnatal period.

questions.text: A study was conducted among a group of 500 patients with lung cancer and another group of 300 people chosen from the general population. Both the groups were questioned about their exposure to smoking. Which of the following cannot be calculated with this study design?
questions.solution:
The study design in the above scenario would be a case-control study. Incidence cannot be calculated from a case-control study.

A case-control is a type of analytical study design that progresses from the effect to the cause, wherein the study population is divided into two groups. In the given example, one group is composed of those who have lung cancer (cases) while the other groups is composed of those who do not have lung cancer (controls). The study can be used to estimate relative risk in cases of rare diseases where the case and control population have almost similar numbers. Here, the odds ratio approaches the relative risk. 

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.

  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. What does point B represent?
questions.solution:
The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by point B, which corresponds to the pK of that compound. 

Other options:

  • The points A represents where the compound is maximally ionised.
  • The point C represents where there is no ionisation of the compound.

This graph represents a titration curve of a weak acid. 

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the aminoacid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • The presence of two pKas indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • The presence of three or more pKas indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

questions.text: A child from Bihar has a fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia. The organism shown below is found to be the causative vector of the underlying condition. Identify the vector.
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical history and the image given in the question, the child is suffering from Kala-azar and the vector for kala-azar is the phlebotomine sandfly. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is an arthropod-borne protozoal infection. The causative vector is the female phlebotomine sandfly, Phlebotomus argentipes. Cutaneous leishmaniasis occurs due to the bite of P. papatasi and P. sergenti. Clinical features of visceral leishmaniasis include anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and fever. In cutaneous leishmaniasis, painful ulcers at the site of sandfly bite may be present. Ulcers around the margins of the mouth and nose may be present in the mucocutaneous variety. 

Preventive measures include the usage of residual insecticides such as DDT (resistant to P. papatasi in North Bihar) in endemic areas. Spraying of insecticides should be done up to a height of 6 feet and at the rate of 1-2 g per sq. meter. Personal protective measures such as the usage of repellent creams and protective nets should be encouraged. Sanitation is also important by eliminating breeding sites such as leftover organic matter, broken mud pots, burrows, and rubbish around the house. 

Other diseases transmitted by phlebotomus include oriental sore and sandfly fever.

Other options:

Option A: Culex mosquitoes are the vector for filariasis.

Option C: Anopheles mosquitoes are the vector for malaria.

Option D: Soft tick is the vector in diseases such as Q fever and relapsing fever. It is shown below.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the physician's office with a history of a new nodule in the neck noted 2 months ago. The patient has a family history of thyroid cancer. Histopathology of the nodule shows the following finding. This patient must be screened for mutations in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Patients with MTC must be screened for RET point mutations so as to distinguish sporadic from familial disease. 

Medullary thyroid cancer(MTC) - 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, familial MTC is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B.

Clinical features - Commonly present as a solitary thyroid nodule. It can present with aerodigestive symptoms such as dysphagia or hoarseness. Lymph node involvement may be seen in some cases.

Diagnosis - Elevated CEA and calcitonin are commonly seen. USG findings may reveal signs of malignancy such as microcalcifications and hypoechoic lesions.

All new patients diagnosed with MTC should be screened for RET point mutations, pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old obese male patient with varicose veins presented to the OPD with an active venous ulcer few months back for which he was treated successfully. However, the ulcer kept on recurring back multiple times. According to the CEAP guidelines, what stage of clinical classification represents the above condition?

CEAP- Clinical etiology anatomy pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders.
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the presence of recurrent active venous ulcer in a patient with varicose veins despite adequate treatment is classified as C6r under the CEAP guidelines.

Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology (CEAP) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

Clinical class C6r represents recurrent active venous ulcers following previous successful treatment or healing.

The image below shows an active venous ulcer.

Other options:

Option A: C4b represents lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche. Lipodermatosclerosis is a chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, that appears as a ‘woody’ leg on examination. Atrophie blanche refers to localized areas of white, atrophic skin, often surrounded by telangiectasia and pigmentation.

Option B: C4c represents corona phlebectatica which is the presence of abnormally visible cutaneous blood vessels. 

Option C: C5 represents a healed venous ulcer

The image below shows a healed venous ulcer.

questions.text: A pathologist examines a peripheral blood smear notices the structure pointed to by the black arrow. The patient's medical history reveals the only significant event as a splenectomy performed six years ago due to an injury. What is the reason for the presence of this structure in the blood smear?
questions.solution:
Howell-Jolly bodies represent nuclear DNA remnants within RBCs. They are small, round, basophilic inclusions that are found in RBCs; The nuclei are normally expelled from RBCs during their maturation in the bone marrow. However, in the absence of a spleen, as in this patient who underwent a splenectomy, Howell-Jolly bodies can remain in RBCs.

Howell-Jolly bodies persist in those with functional hyposplenism or asplenia:

  • Autosplenectomy due to sickle cell anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
  • Radiation therapy
  • Severe hemolytic anemia
  • Splenectomy following trauma

Option B: Heinz bodies contain denatured Hb that appears purple-blue on the supravital stain; They're seen in G6PD deficiency.

Option C: Cabot rings are made of microtubule remnants from a mitotic spindle. They're seen in:

  • Asplenia
  • Lead poisoning
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Thalassemia

Option D: Basophilic stippling is seen as blue granules of various sizes are dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of RBCS: They are ribosomal  precipitates. Seen in lead poisoning and thalassemia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old design intern was brought to casualty by his colleagues with a history of acute onset euphoric excitement followed by weariness, headache, giddiness, and intense drowsiness. The pupils were bilaterally constricted, the face and lips cyanosed.  As per his friends, he had a substance abuse issue and often stayed at late-night parties. His vitals which were normal on arrival are recorded as follows after a short duration. PR-80bpm, RR-10/min, BP- 88/58mmHg. He gradually passes into a deep coma, with fixed pinpoint pupils, and the breathing pattern is as shown in the graph. Which of the following can cause symptoms as described?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing the stage of euphoria, stupor, and narcosis with pinpoint pupils and Cheyne-Stokes breathing is suggestive of Morphine or Opioid toxicity.

Characteristics of opioid (morphine) toxicity:

  • Stage of Excitement 

Characterized by a euphoric feeling of well-being initially which is of short duration due to effects on the limbic system. The breath may smell of opium.

  • Stage of Stupor 

The stage of excitement is followed by weariness, headache, giddiness, heaviness in limbs, decreased sensibility, and increased sleepiness from which the patient can be aroused by applying external stimuli. The pupils are constricted, the face and lips cyanosed. The pulse and respiration are normal in this stage.

  • Stage of Narcosis 

The patient passes into a deep coma from which he cannot be aroused. The muscles are relaxed and the reflex absent. The pupils are constricted to pinpoint and unresponsive to light (due to the depression of supranuclear inhibition of the pupillary constrictor tone). The blood pressure falls and the pulse is weak. Decreased motility of the GIT occurs with constipation and anorexia. Emptying of the stomach is also delayed.

The breathing is slow and irregular and the respiratory rate may fall to 2 to 4 per minute. This results from a decreased response of the brainstem to carbon dioxide tension and is known as Cheyne Stokes Breathing. The temperature is decreased, and the skin cold and sweaty. Death usually occurs from asphyxia due to respiratory paralysis, which may be preceded by convulsions.

Note:

Miosis is not universally present from intoxication with every opioid; normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity. Opioid-induced acute lung injury, previously known as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, is an uncommon complication associated with heroin overdose. Black/ grayish postmortem lividity is seen in the case of opium poisoning.

Unripe capsule of Papaver somniferum.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant. CNS stimulation (anxiety, hyperactivity), CVS overactivity(tachycardia, hypertension), and increased respiratory rate are seen in poisoning with cocaine causing sympathetic toxidrome.

The water-soluble form(-hydrochloride) can be injected or snorted. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks. Whilst another form (-sulphate), can be smoked. It gives a cracking sound when burnt

It inhibits the uptake of Dopamine, Norepinephrine and Serotonin. It hence presents with the action of these neurotransmitters

At lower doses-it produces confidence, alertness but at higher doses- it produces stereotyped behaviour, involuntary actions, paranoia. There is a transient euphoria, which makes the person crave for more. The hallucination of tactile type may occur with impaired judgement. There is a dose-dependent increase in heart rate and BP and may cause arrhythmias. It causes dilation of pupils and is associated with chills and perspiration. Ultimately, the patient goes into a stage of depression with loss of reflexes, paralysis of muscles, cardiorespiratory failure and coma.

Initial management involves the administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage if it has been ingested.

Treatment involves the administration of benzodiazepines to control heart rate/seizures, propanolol to control cardiac arrhythmia and haloperidol to treat psychosis. Counselling needs to be done to avoid resist the urge for repetitive usage. 

The image shows Erythroxylum cocca. Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in these plants.

Tetrahydrocannabinol is obtained from cannabis. Cannabis addiction is a chronic poisoning state resulting from continued use of the drug in any form and is characterized by anorexia, loss of weight, weakness, tremors, impotence, and moral deterioration.

The victim might become lethargic, apathetic, and disinterested to work and suffer from poor concentration. This is called Amotivational syndrome. In acute poisoning, few individuals may turn violent and go into a state called run amok.

The image shows cannabis plant.

Jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

All Datura species contain the anticholinergic alkaloids atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked and produce delirium, hallucinations, and seizures along with other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia. Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion; thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

questions.text: In evaluating a 55 year old patient for Parkinson's Disease, which of the following features would raise a red flag for a Parkinson-plus syndrome?
questions.solution:
Out of the four options, autonomic dysfunction at the diagnostic/early stage should raise suspicion for a Parkinson-plus syndrome, specifically for Multiple System Atrophy. (MSA)

MSA comprises of autonomic dysfunction and either parkinsonism or cerebellar findings. The parkinsonism seen in MSA is atypical because it is *symmetrical and axial*. The tremor is also not prominent. Although autonomic abnormalities can be seen in advanced PD, they are more severe and generalized in MSA. This patient is being evaluated for PD, and early autonomic dysfunction is not a sign of typical PD. Autonomic dysfunction often presents as orthostatic hypotension, which can cause symptoms ranging from dimming of vision to syncope. Syncope occurs when the drop in BP impairs cerebral perfusion. Symptomatic orthostatic hypotension occuring within 1 year of onset of parkinsonism is typically encountered in MSA.

*Note that Parkinsonism is a broad term that is used when bradykinesia, *asymmetric rigidity and/or asymmetric, low-frequency tremor are present together. (Options A and D)

The non-motor manifestations of PD include:

*Anosmia due to olfactory dysfunction. (Option B)
Sensory symptoms such as pain
Mood disorders such as depression
Sleep disturbances
