questions.text: Kegel exercises are indicated in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Patients with overflow incontinence are managed with intermittent self catheterization.

Causes of overflow incontinence include:

  • Detrusor areflexia or a hypotonic bladder, as seen in LMN disease, injury to spinal cord, or autonomic neuropathy (diabetes mellitus)
  • Urinary outflow obstruction.
  • Postoperative urinary retention.

 

Kegel pelvic floor exercises involve intermittent tightening of the perineal muscles which leads to strengthening of the pelvic floor muscles and decreases the urethral mobility.

They are indicated in following conditions:

  • Before and after delivery to reduce the risk of postpartum urinary incontinence.
  • As first-line therapy in patients with stress urinary incontinence.
  • Overactive Bladder /Urge Urinary Incontinence.
  • To limit the progression and alleviate symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse.
  • Fecal Incontinence

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, G2P1L1 at 33 weeks of gestation is admitted to the hospital for management of spontaneous preterm labor. What is the dose of dexamethasone administered to stimulate fetal lung maturation in her?
questions.solution:
The dose of dexamethasone administered to stimulate fetal lung maturation is 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), periventricular leukomalacia (PVL), overall neonatal mortality, and neurodevelopmental impairment. 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. The dose of Betamethasone is 12 mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infections. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labour in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labour, and placental abruption.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can convert phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid?
questions.solution:
The phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction is a characteristic feature that distinguishes Proteus from other enterobacteria. All members of the Proteus tribe have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. Phenyl pyruvic acid imparts a green color. The test is given below:

Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. 

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.

Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as:

Lactose fermenters

Escherichia, Klebsiella,Enterobacter 

Late lactose fermenters

Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia

Non-lactose fermenters

Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S Sonnie which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

Other options:

Klebsiella (Option A) and Enterobacter (Option D) are lactose-fermenters on MacConkey's medium. Serratia (Option C) is a late lactose fermenter.

questions.text:
A chronic alcoholic patient presented with acute epigastric pain radiating to the back. On examination, the following sign is seen as shown in the image below. Lab investigations showed elevated serum amylase and lipase. What are the possible complications of the underlying condition?
  1. Coeliac artery thrombosis
  2. Pseudocyst formation
  3. Splenic vein thrombosis
  4. Sterile necrotic collection
  5. Infected necrotic collection
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the grey turner's sign (discoloration of the flanks) are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All the above-mentioned options could be possible complications except celiac artery thrombosis.

Acute pancreatitis can result in local and systemic complications. Local complications develop after the first week of the event and include:

Complication Description Management
Pancreatic pseudocyst
  • A well-encapsulated amylase-rich fluid collection outside the pancreas formed around 4 weeks after an attack of pancreatitis.
  • The fluid shows low CEA levels and cytology shows inflammatory cells.
  • Spontaneous resolution is common
  • Asymptomatic chronic thick-walled cysts may necessitate endoscopic, surgical, or percutaneous drainage due to the risk of complications. 
Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC)
  •  A collection of sterile fluid in the peripancreatic tissues without encapsulation.

Usually resolves without any intervention but a large fluid collection may necessitate imaging-guided aspiration and drainage.
Sterile and infected pancreatic necrosis
  • Diffuse or localized peripancreatic fat breakdown results in a necrotic collection within and around the pancreas - acute necrotic collection(ANC).
  • The collection consists of fluid and necrotic material with an ill-defined wall that may be initially sterile but later become infected.
  • Over a period of time, the capsule is well formed and called a walled Off necrosis (WON).
 Management includes conservative measures and percutaneous drainage. In patients with overwhelming sepsis, laparotomy may be needed to perform a necrosectomy. Continuous post-operative closed lavage may be needed to prevent a recurrence.
Splenic vein thrombosis As a result of the procoagulant state during acute pancreatitis. Anti-platelet drugs. Endoscopic banding and beta blockers are used in the case of portal hypertension.

 
Pancreatic abscess A circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus around the pancreas. Imaging-guided percutaneous drainage under the cover of antibiotics
Pancreatic ascites

A generalized peritoneal effusion resulting from pancreatic duct disruption.

Amylase-rich fluid will be obtained through paracentesis.

 Imaging guided drainage with wide-bore drains
Hemorrhage Bleeding into the pseudocyst cavity or from a raw surface or pseudoaneurysm arising from a peripancreatic vessel. Embolization or surgery


The image given below shows pancreatic pseudocyst on a CT scan.

Systemic complications result from multi-organ damage and include acute respiratory distress syndrome, pleural effusions, gastrointestinal hemorrhage, renal failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: Vascular complications of pancreatitis

Arterial pseudoaneurysm:

  • It is caused by damage to the vessel wall by pancreatic elastase
  • The most common vessel affected is the splenic artery, but the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), cystic artery, and gastroduodenal artery (GDA) may also be affected
  • Spontaneous rupture results in massive bleeding
  • Clinical manifestations include sudden onset of abdominal pain, tachycardia, and hypotension.
  • CT angiography is the investigation of choice
  • Treatment
    • Arterial embolization
    • Ligation of the affected vessel in refrac­tory cases

Vascular thrombosis:

  • The vessel usually affected is the splenic vein, but in severe cases, it can extend into the portal venous system
  • Clinical features include splenomegaly, gastric varices, and splenic vein occlusion
  • Treatment:
    • Mostly conservative
    • Throm­bolytics in the acute early phase

questions.text: Which of the following spirometry results can be expected in a patient with emphysema?

choices.text: High RV, Low FRC, High TLC, High FEV1/FVC
High RV, High FRC, Low TLC, Low FEV1/FVC
High RV, Low FRC, Low TLC, Normal FEV1/FVC
High RV, High FRC, High TLC, Low FEV1/FVC

questions.solution:
In emphysema, an obstructive lung disease, a high residual volume, high functional residual capacity, high total lung capacity is seen along with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio.

In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduce, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases. The total lung capacity is increased in emphysema. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD/Emphysema, FRC is increased.

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease commonly seen in patients who are between 50–75 years of age with dyspnea being severe very early in the disease, and late-onset cough with scanty sputum. They are often referred to as "pink puffers" due to their typical thin non-cyanotic (pink) appearance with severe dyspnea even at rest. 

Emphysema occurs due to irreversible dilatation and destruction of airspace walls distal to terminal bronchioles. It is particularly severe in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and in smokers. Lung tissue destruction is caused by toxic injury, protease-antiprotease imbalance, oxidative stress, and infection. As a result, the diffusing capacity may be reduced.

In emphysema, the upper two-thirds of the lungs are markedly affected. Due to hyperinflation, the lungs become voluminous completely eclipsing the heart anteriorly.  On microscopy, a thin septum with focal centriacinar fibrosis is seen between abnormally large alveoli. Airspaces with blebs or bullae are seen in advanced disease. There is a loss of elastic tissue in the walls of alveoli in the proximity of bronchioles, due to which there is respiratory collapse during expiration. X-ray shows the presence of hyperinflated lung fields.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman who presented with abnormal uterine bleeding is scheduled for endometrial biopsy. In her case file, you see her transvaginal sonography report. What is the endometrial thickness you are expecting to see?
questions.solution:
In a postmenopausal woman with abnormal uterine bleeding, investigations like endometrial sampling is indicated when the endometrial thickness is >4 mm. Since the patient is posted for an endometrial biopsy, the thickness of her endometrium is likely to be more than 4 mm. 

Timing Endometrial thickness
Immediately after menstruation 1–2 mm
Early proliferative phase 5–7 mm
Secretory phase 7–16 mm
Preovulatory phase  up to 12 mm
Postmenopausal (Asymptomatic) <4 mm
Postmenopausal with bleeding; investigations should start when the thickness is >4 mm

An endometrial biopsy can be done by

  • Dilatation and curettage
  • Uterine cavity aspiration using a pipelle and endometrial sampling (office biopsy)

Indications for endometrial sampling:

  • Any woman aged >45 years with abnormal uterine bleeding
  • A woman aged <45 years with exposure to excessive estrogen, such as those with polycystic ovary disease, severe obesity, or tamoxifen treatment
  • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding
  • Transvaginal ultrasound showing an endometrial thickness of >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women

questions.text: Impairment of ATP hydrolysis in the phenomenon shown below will most likely affect which of the following processes?

choices.text: Release of norepinephrine into the synaptic cleft
Movement of urea into the medullary interstitium
Utilisation of glucose by the RBC
Iodine trapping by the thryoid follicular cell

questions.solution:
The image in the questions depicts a Na+ and K+-ATPase pump and an impairment in the hydrolysis of ATP could lead to defective iodine trapping by the thyroid follicular cell as it is a symporter whose function is dependent on the energy stored in the cell following ATP hydrolysis. 

ATP-dependent transporters transfer molecules/ions across the membrane using ATP energy. There are two types of ATP-dependent transporters: ATPase ion and ATP-binding cassette(ABC). ATPases are categorized into P-type, V-type ion transporters and F-type ion transporters.

  • P-type ATPases like Na+, and K+-ATPase are significant. Hydrolysis of each ATP molecule removes three Na+ ions and brings two K+ ions into the cell. All cells have Na+, K+-ATPase, which maintains cell volume and creates cellular ion and electrical gradients.
  • V-type H+-ATPases present in the intercalated cells of the kidney aid in the acidification of urine. V-type H+-ATPases are found in the membranes of various intracellular organelles, such as endosomes and lysosomes. Also, V-type ion transporters also aid in the membrane fusion and release of neurotransmitters such as glutamate and norepinephrine.
  • F-type ATPases are found in mitochondria and play a role in ATP synthesis. 

Mechanism of the Na+ and K+-ATPase pump.

Other options:

Option A: The release of norepinephrine into the synaptic cleft is with the aid of the H+- ATPase channel which is a V-type ion transporter. However, the diagram in the question depicts a Na+ and K+-ATPase channel, hence ruling this out as an option.

Option B: The movement of urea into the medullary interstitium is an example of facilitated diffusion and does not require the hydrolysis of ATP.

Option C: The utilisation of glucose by the RBC is also another example of facilitated diffusion and does not require the hydrolysis of ATP.

questions.text: A veterinarian comes with complaints of fever, cough, and dyspnea. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a veterinarian(at risk for exposure to anthrax spores) with complaints of cough and fever with a chest X-ray showing widening of the mediastinum is suggestive of pulmonary anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis. The widened mediastinum is due to significant lymphadenopathy.

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

  • Cutaneous Anthrax(hide porter’s disease)- Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • Pulmonary Anthrax(Wool sorter’s disease)- Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • Intestinal Anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

On microscopy, they appear as gram-positive rods. Bacilli are arranged end to end in long chains. The ends of the bacilli are truncated or often concave and somewhat swollen so that a chain of bacilli presents a bamboo stick appearance.

The organisms produce nonhemolytic grey-to-white, tenacious colonies with a rough texture and a ground-glass appearance in blood agar. Comma-shaped outgrowths (Medusa head, curled hair) may project from the colony.

Treatment is with doxycycline or fluoroquinolone. Systemic disease is also additionally treated with the antitoxin.

questions.text: Which of the following trace minerals is essential for glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Chromium potentiates the action of insulin in patients with impaired glucose tolerance, presumably by increasing insulin receptor-mediated signaling.

Rich food sources of chromium include: yeast, meat, grain products

Chromium in the trivalent state is largely nontoxic however, chromium-6 is a known pulmonary carcinogen as well as a cause of liver, kidney, and CNS damage.

Option B: Selenium deficiency can lead to thyroid dysfunction, cardiomyopathies, and immune dysfunction.

Option C: Iron deficiency can present with microcytic anemia and/or restless leg syndrome.

Option D: Zinc deficiency may present with acrodermatitis enteropathica; alopecia, pustular skin rash over extremities/perioral region, hypogonadism, impaired wound healing, dysguesia, and immune dysfunction.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty ward following a road traffic accident. His GCS score was declining over time. His CT scan was found to be normal but brain MRI showed the following findings. What kind of force acting on the brain is responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Force opposite to the direct impact

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient presenting with a decreased GCS score following an RTA with susceptibility-weighted MRI image (SWI) demonstrating hypointense foci of microhemorrhages is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI) is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain, due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration commonly seen in high-velocity road traffic accidents. This causes extensive damage in the microvasculature and disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, corpus callosum, and midbrain.

Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. Mechanical forces cause direct damage to axons, which changes the axoplasmic flow. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

CT may be normal. MRI, especially SWI, is the investigation of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain. It detects the micro-bleeds within the brain.

Other options:

Options B and D: The most common type of traumatic parenchymal brain injury is a contusion, caused by the direct impact of the brain against the skull base. Conversely, contre-coup contusions occur in the brain parenchyma opposite the site of direct impact. It is a focal phenomenon, unlike DAI which causes more extensive damage.

Option C: Most cervical spinal cord injuries are the result of axial loading (force directed through the top of the head and through the spine) forcing the head into hyperflexion and/or rotation. One or more cervical vertebrae may fracture or dislocate as a result of this kind of mechanism.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant labourer who is HIV-positive delivers a healthy male baby. She was advised ART previously but has been non-compliant with her treatment. What is recommended by NACO with regards to feeding the baby?
questions.solution:
NACO recommends exclusive breastfeeding as the infant feeding choice in the first 6 months. This is irrespective of the fact that the mother is on ART or the infant is provided with ARV prophylaxis for 6 weeks.

Breast-feeding and replacement feed simultaneously (mixed feeds) in the first 6 months should not be done, as it leads to mucosal abrasions in the gut of the baby, thereby facilitating HIV entry.

Breast-feeding should not be stopped abruptly. Only in situations where breastfeeding cannot be done (maternal death, severe maternal illness) or individual mother’s choice (at her own risk), then exclusive replacement feeding which is safe, sustainable, affordable and feasible can be started.

In resource-rich settings/developed countries, exclusive alternative formulations are recommended.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of bleeding from the nose after a fistfight. On evaluation, it was found to be a vertical fracture of the nasal septum. What is the name of the fracture suffered by this patient?
questions.solution:
Since it is a vertical fracture of the nasal septum, it is called a Chevallet fracture.

Injuries to the nasal septum can result from trauma to the nose from the front, side, or below. The septum may get buckled on itself, fracture vertically, horizontally, or get crushed.

A Chevallet fracture usually results from a blow to the nose from below. This fracture line runs vertically. It extends from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

A Jarjaway fracture results from a blow to the nose from the front. The fracture line runs horizontally backward. It begins just above the anterior nasal spine and extends just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer. 

Patients with septal injuries with mucosal tears present with profuse epistaxis. Those with an intact mucosa may have a septal hematoma, which should be drained. 

Dislocated or fractured fragments of the septum should be repositioned and supported. This is done with mucoperichondrial flaps, mattress sutures, and nasal packing.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not seen in pregnant women with normal cardiovascular function?
questions.solution:
Left axis deviation is seen in pregnancy as there is a lateral displacement of the cardiac apex by the gravid uterus.

Other Options:

Option B: Resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min during pregnancy and hence physiological tachycardia may be noted.

Option C: Pregnancy is a hypervolemic state, and S3 is audible due to the rapid diastolic filling.

Option D: Pregnancy may be associated with benign pericardial effusion.

 

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A young man presents with painful swelling and redness of his right testis. On examination, the epididymis is tender, swollen, and erythematous, and Prehn sign is positive. There is no discharge from the urethra. Which of the following is an appropriate antibiotic?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain, swelling of the epididymis and a positive Prehn's sign likely has epididymitis and is best treated with Ceftriaxone.

Epididymitis is usually caused by sexually transmitted bacteria in younger men or urinary pathogens in older men. Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men (>40 years) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from a urinary infection, most commonly caused by Escherichia coli.

Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and tenderness of the epididymis, with or without symptoms or signs of urethritis

Prehn’s sign differentiates testes torsion from acute epididymitis. In the latter, the pain is relieved by elevating the testis.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support. Treatment with antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone and/or doxycycline, is effective for STB-related epididymitis, while levofloxacin or ofloxacin is effective for epididymitis caused by Enterobacteriaceae.

Treatment:

  • Younger men: Ceftriaxone (500 mg as a single dose IM) followed by Doxycycline (100 mg by mouth twice daily for 10 days)
  • Older men: Oral Levofloxacin (500 mg once daily for 10 days) or Ofloxacin (300 mg twice daily for 10 days) if Enterobacteriaceae infection is suspected.

Options B and C: Are effective against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobes and are not appropriate for epididymitis.

Option D: TMP-SMX is a second-line antibiotic for epididymitis.

questions.text: All the given statements about phenytoin are true except:

choices.text: Avoid phenytoin in females on oral contraceptives
Phenytoin is useful in absence seizures
Vitamin K and D are used to treat osteomalacia of phenytoin

questions.solution:
Phenytoin is effective in all types of focal and generalized tonic-clonic seizures but is not useful in absence seizures. 

Pharmacokinetics: Phenytoin is available in oral, intramuscular, and intravenous formulations. It follows mixed order/saturation kinetics i.e., at low serum concentration, it follows first-order kinetics and as serum concentration increases, it changes to zero-order kinetics.

Phenytoin is a CYP enzyme inducer that leads to increased degradation of drugs such as oral contraceptive pills and leads to unplanned pregnancies.

Mechanism of action: Phenytoin slows the recovery of Na+ channels from inactivation thus decreasing the conduction of action potential.

The therapeutic concentration of phenytoin- 10-20 μgm/ml.

Therapeutic uses:

  • Focal seizures
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Status epilepticus
  • Digoxin induced ventricular arrhythmia
  • Trigeminal neuralgia

It is not useful in absence seizures, myoclonic epilepsy, and Dravet syndrome.

Side effects of phenytoin include:

  • Hirsutism
  • Gingival hyperplasia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypersensitivity reactions
  • Osteomalacia (requires both Vitamin D and K for treatment)
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome (hypoplastic phalanges, cleft palate, hare lip, microcephaly)
  • Purple glove syndrome

Dose-related toxicity of phenytoin causes ataxia, vertigo, diplopia, and nystagmus.

Phenytoin increases the metabolism of vitamin K and decreases the vitamin-k dependant proteins required for the normal Ca2+ metabolism of bone. Hence vitamin K is required along with vitamin D for the treatment of osteomalacia.

A better alternative for IV phenytoin:

Instead of phenytoin, IV fosphenytoin is preferred in the management of status epilepticus. It is a pro-drug and is rapidly converted to phenytoin. Fosphenytoin decreases the incidence of purple glove syndrome.

questions.text: The type of uterine fibromyoma in the image
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Submucous type of uterine fibromyoma.

Uterine myomas are broadly classified into 3 types.

They are-

  • Intramural - remains within the myometrial wall.
  • Submucous - present inside the uterine cavity and covered only by a thin endometrium.
  • Subserous - present towards the peritoneal surface.

Treatment includes:

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid
  • Uterine artery embolization.
  • Myomectomy.
  • Total / subtotal hysterectomy.

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn is referred to you with recurrent vomiting and diarrhea. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Based on further evaluation, a diagnosis of classical galactosemia is made. This baby is most susceptible to sepsis caused by:
questions.solution:
Infants with classical galactosemia are susceptible to recurrent sepsis caused by Escherichia coli.

Classical galactosemia is caused to deficient galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. The enzyme is responsible for the conversion of galactose 1-phosphate to glucose-1-phosphate in the metabolism of galactose.  

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

questions.text: The MR angiography of a patient is shown below. Which of the following structures is predominantly supplied by the artery marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image of MR angiography is the anterior cerebral artery. It predominantly supplies the corpus callosum.

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.  

The images below show the MR angiography and the cadaveric image of the Circle of Willis, respectively. 

The anterior cerebral artery is a terminal branch of the internal carotid artery. 

The anterior cerebral arteries course along the great longitudinal fissure, passing around the curve of the genu of the corpus callosum along its upper surface and ends to anastomose with posterior cerebral arteries. It gives the following branches.

Cortical branches  Areas supplied

1. Orbital branches 

  
  • Olfactory cortex
  • Gyrus rectus
  • Medial orbital gyrus
2. Frontal branches
  • Corpus callosum
  • Cingulate gyrus
  • Medial frontal gyrus
  • Paracentral lobule
  • Fornix
 3. Parietal branches
  •  Precuneus
Central branches
  • Rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Septum pellucidum
  • Anterior part of the putamen, Head of the caudate nucleus and adjacent parts of the internal capsule
 

The cortical branches of the anterior cerebral artery supply the motor and somatosensory areas of the cerebral cortex that represent the lower limb.

Other options:

Option A: The thalamus is supplied by posterior communicating arteries, posterior cerebral arteries, and the basilar artery. 

Option B: The medulla oblongata is supplied by the vertebral artery, anterior and posterior spinal arteries, posterior inferior cerebellar arteries, and basilar artery. 

Option C: The midbrain is supplied by posterior cerebral arteries, superior cerebellar arteries, and the basilar artery. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.
